subject: A new digital transformation playbook, hotels of the future, nondisruptive innovation, and more: The Daily Read Weekender
body:
Catch up on this week's insights ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
CURATED PICKS FOR YOUR DOWNTIME, FROM OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
The last weekend of July is upon us. As you settle in and unwind, catch up on digital transformations in the age of AI, the future of the hospitality industry, creating new market solutions without disrupting existing industries, and more.
 
Are you rewired to win? The latest 
Five Fifty
 from 
McKinsey Quarterly
 shows why digital transformations are more important than ever in the age of generative AI.
Unlock the power of AI
 
What will staying at a hotel be like in 2030? See how the hospitality industry will evolve to benefit travelers, workers, and the environment in McKinsey’s 
The Next Normal
 series.
Check into the hotel of the future
 
In a new 
Author Talks
 interview, professor Renée Mauborgne talks to McKinsey’s Elissa Bandler about how companies can innovate without disrupting industries or displacing jobs.
Push the boundaries
 
Our weekly briefing note on sustainable and inclusive growth explores how technological advancements in bioengineering and shared-mobility solutions are helping to solve global challenges.
Get updated
TECH FOR EXECS
 
The rise and rise of Python
Welcome to Tech for Execs: quick primers on technology concepts to get business leaders up to speed.
Why do people choose Python?
 
It’s a go-to language
 for back-end development, software, data science, and machine learning. It’s easy to learn and integrates with other languages—so it can find its place within pre-existing architectures without too much trouble.
What are the biggest benefits?
 Python is great for creating automated processes, which save time. Its popularity means there are thousands of existing packages—ready-to-use ‘chunks’ of code—out there. And it’s easy to read and debug, and therefore it’s simple to fix if something does go wrong.
How are organizations using Python?
 It’s 
particularly popular for data science applications
. At McKinsey, we used Python in our work with a healthcare organization to help 
improve COVID-19 capacity modelling
. Because when you’re dealing with complex data lakes and working at speed, simplicity is a virtue.
Do my developers know how to use Python?
 There’s a good chance they do—it’s one of the more popular languages available. Even if they don’t, experienced developers can usually pick the language up quickly.
If we start using Python, does that mean starting over?
 Not necessarily—Python plays well with other languages. Plus, there’s no shortage of packages and frameworks out there to accelerate your work. One example is 
Kedro, McKinsey’s open-source framework
, which simplifies and standardizes data science coding.
QUOTE OF THE DAY
“Children need to have family time. They need to be able to talk with their parents, have hobbies, and eat dinner together. These types of things are so important, more important than a worksheet—and that’s coming from a former teacher.”
—
Jamie Sears
, founder and CEO of Not So Wimpy Teacher, on how we should be thinking differently about homework, in a 
recent 
Author Talks
 interview
chart of the day
 
See today’s chart
Ready to unwind?
What is space junk?
Space junk refers to fragments left behind in space. Consisting mostly of rocket-launching material and disused satellites, this debris can make space travel and exploration more challenging.
Find out what’s in orbit
 
Data Points: Your weekly quiz
How well do you know the numbers behind the changes in business, society, and the world? Take the McKinsey weekly quiz to find out.
Take the quiz
 
11-Down: Word with chocolate or sauce
Know the answer? Test yourself with the latest McKinsey Crossword, Uncapitalized Food | No. 138.
Take a bite
 
—Edited by Joy Merten, editor, Chicago

subject: That Time I Was Upstaged by LexisNexis 😂
body:
I was ready to tell you about a recent client success story, but then I posted this on LinkedIn and was delightfully upstaged.
 
 
Hi Jacob!
 
Yes, you really can generate revenue from social sharing!
 
I was ready to tell you about a recent client success story — how a single share 
generated $136K in revenue
 — but then I posted this on LinkedIn and was delightfully upstaged. 😂
 
Ben Guilfoy, social media manager at LexisNexis (another EveryoneSocial client), replied to my post to share how his company once got a $400K contract from a Twitter DM. 🤯
 
☝️ This is what employee advocacy is all about!
 
Getting your people to consistently share your company's content and news produces SO MANY benefits: awareness, engagement, reach, and revenue.
 
Our client’s success story was the focus of 
a recent webinar
 hosted by EveryoneSocial’s client success team. These webinars are intended for social media managers and other practitioners involved with running advocacy programs.
 
But you don’t have to be an EveryoneSocial customer to join — they’re open to all!
 
Topics focus on employee advocacy strategy, best practices, and success stories. In short, things to help you build and sustain a successful advocacy program at your company, regardless of what tools you use.
 
The next one will be August 23 at 1 p.m. ET. 
Register Now.
 
Thanks for reading, and I hope you have a wonderful weekend!
 
Best,
 
Cameron Brain 
CEO & Co-Founder
EveryoneSocial
 
P.S. - Feel free to connect with me on 
LinkedIn
 or 
Twitter
!
Make sure to follow us on social media!
 
 
 
 
EveryoneSocial, 215 W Sego Lily Dr., #708100, Sandy, Utah 84070, United States

subject: What are the most significant tech trends of 2023?
body:
15 technologies to watch ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Transformational technologies
In the news
•
Privacy concerns.
 Employers are certain that generative-AI platforms could boost workers’ productivity. What they are less sure of is whether the technology would expose confidential information to rivals or bad actors. Executives are therefore worried about both “missing out” on and “messing up” the generative-AI opportunity, says the head of one law firm’s machine learning practice. In February 2023, a telecom company became one of a handful of large US employers to ban or limit using generative AI at work. [
WaPo
]
•
Geographic winners.
 From the rise of personal computing to the birth of social media, Silicon Valley’s influence over the global tech sector has lasted decades. The generative-AI boom could strengthen the region’s dominance in technology. One in four generative-AI jobs in the past year were listed in the Bay Area, per a Brookings Institution analysis of about 2,200 job postings in roughly 380 US metro areas. Hubs that become early tech adopters often long benefit from the financial assets and skilled workforces associated with those technologies. [
NYT
]
In the coming decade, 20 to 30% of the time that workers spend on the job could be transformed by automation technologies.
On McKinsey.com
•
AI’s next frontier.
 After a tough year for tech talent and investment in 2022, enthusiasm for technology is growing. To help leaders track the latest developments, the McKinsey Technology Council—including chair 
Lareina Yee
 and coauthors—identified 15 of the most significant tech trends. Last year’s 14 trends remain relevant. One new trend, generative AI, could add as much as $4.4 trillion in economic value annually. Even so, generative AI is just one of many advances that could propel growth and solve complex challenges
.
•
Search for skills.
 Between technology’s potential to add value and organizations’ ability to realize growth lies the great gulf of talent. Many of the most in-demand skills for these tech trends have less than half as many qualified practitioners per posting as the global average, our survey of 3.5 million job postings reveals. Companies should be ready to respond to shifts in the talent market (such as recent layoffs in the tech sector) and continue to look at how they can adjust roles and upskill workers. See the most noteworthy 
tech trends of 2023
.
Understand key technologies
— Edited by Belinda Yu, editor, Atlanta

—we’d love to hear from you.

subject: Achieving growth in consumer goods through a multi-lens approach
body:
Take a multipronged approach ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Growth matters—especially during times of economic uncertainty. 
And weathering the challenges of the moment is worthwhile because companies that grow during economic downturns tend to outperform when the economy recovers. Using advanced analytics to make the right choices about “where to play”—or determining which categories, geographic markets, channels, and business models to focus on—while adopting insights from multiple lenses can help consumer goods companies achieve profitable growth, say McKinsey’s 
Björn Timelin
, 
Chris Enger
, 
Julie Lowrie
, 
Ryan Murphy
, and their coauthors. 
Check out the article
 to understand why deep analyses of consumers, categories, competitors, and capabilities should be integrated into your growth road map.
 
A multi-lens approach to finding growth in consumer goods
Achieving profitable growth is hard, but using analytics to better understand consumers, categories, competitors, and capabilities can improve the odds of consistently outperforming.
﻿Take a multipronged approach
Quote of the day
“As machines get better at being machines, humans have to get better at being more human. . . . So human empathy, EQ, et cetera, will all become more important for employment.”
—
Andrew J. Scott, professor of economics at the London Business School, on the effects of AI on older workers in a 
recent episode
 of McKinsey Global Institute’s 
Forward Thinking
 podcast
Chart of the day
 
﻿See today’s chart
ALSO NEW
A bigger, bolder vision: How CROs are propelling growth from the C-suite
Chief revenue officers are boosting revenue at not only start-ups but also established companies.
4 traits 
 
Author Talks: How educators can avoid burnout and embrace self-care
It’s arguably never been tougher to be a teacher. In a new book, educator Jamie Sears helps teachers navigate the classroom, manage relationships with parents, and define what success is.
Celebrate wins  
M&A, value creation, and the automotive aftermarket
New McKinsey analysis highlights seven themes for creating value through M&A in the automotive aftermarket and measures European executives’ sentiments.

subject: [Important Notice]: Extended Security Support for PHP 7.4 & PHP 8.0 EOL
body:
At WP Engine, serving you is our purpose, and we are focused on the continuous delivery of that value. We appreciate you trusting your sites and digital presence to WP Engine. We are writing to inform you of important updates regarding PHP. 
PHP 7.4 Extended Security Support:
 
WP Engine is pleased to announce that we will continue to invest in ongoing security support of PHP 7.4 through 2024, as WordPress and a wide range of themes and plugins are still not fully compatible with PHP 8.0+, which could lead to critical errors on some websites. 
PHP 8.0 End-of-Life:
PHP 8.0 will reach end-of-life (EOL) and no longer receive security support by the end of the year. In response to this, 
WP Engine will begin the EOL process for PHP 8.0, which means PHP 8.0 will no longer be available on the WP Engine platform by November 2023. 
WP Engine will perform automatic upgrades of all sites still on PHP 8.0 to PHP 8.2 before November and will communicate more specific dates in the coming weeks. You can read more about the upgrade process 
here 
. 
What does this mean for you?
 
We encourage you to take advantage of PHP 8.2 now - there is no need to wait for your automatic upgrade. PHP 8.2 is a minor version change and a significantly easier upgrade process. Our recommendation is to use our 
PHP Test Driver 
, which allows you to preview your site on PHP 8.2, without impacting the live content your visitors see.
After using the PHP Test Driver to verify your website is functioning as expected, please use our 
PHP Selector 
in the User Portal to perform your upgrade. It's that simple! 
Our team of WordPress experts are available 24/7 to assist with any questions you may have. Thank you for the opportunity to serve your business. 
Need help? 
Contact our 
Support Team 
. 
© WP Engine | 504 Lavaca St. Suite 1000 | Austin, TX 78701 
Not the right contact for this account? Please forward on to the appropriate person, and be sure to update your account's users in 
User Portal 
.

subject: 📚 Elevate Your HR Strategies: Register Now for Three Exclusive Webinars!
body:
🎯 Level up your HR game! Engaging webinars on hybrid learning, onboarding success, and effective management await you.
 
Hi Jacob,
 
We're excited to invite you to not one, but three amazing webinars designed to empower you with valuable insights and innovative strategies. Whether you're a seasoned professional or just starting your journey, these webinars offer something for everyone looking to enhance their skills and make a meaningful impact.
 
Can't make our webinar sessions live?
 Don't stress. We will share the video for you to download or view on demand. Just make sure you register.
💜 TODAY! Learning in a Hybrid World
 
Only a few hours left to register for this exciting and engaging webinar, 
“4 Steps to Make Your Learning Program Work in a Hybrid World.”
 
During this session, you’ll hear from Hannah Hafenrichter, Manager, Global Talent Development and Employee Experience at Enboarder give actionable insights into how using a human-centric approach when building your HR programs and putting yourself in your employees' shoes offers the best possible learning experience.
Date: 
TODAY!
Time: 
2
:00pm ET / 11:00am PT
SAVE YOUR SEAT
 
This Program has been approved for 0.50 HR (General) recertification credit hours toward aPHR™, aPHRi™, PHR®, PHRca®, SPHR®, GPHR®, PHRi™ and SPHRi™recertification through HR Certification Institute® (HRCI®).
😎 Stop Stressing about Onboarding
 
Are you looking to streamline your onboarding processes, reduce turnover rates, and boost productivity and performance? If your answer is yes, you won't want to miss our upcoming webinar on talent & onboarding. 
 
Join us for this webinar to see how Enboarder can help your organization create a great first impression for new hires, inspire managers in hiring, onboarding, and career development, and build a best-in-class employer brand.
 
Date:
 August 8, 2023
Time: 
2:00pm ET / 11:00am PT
SAVE YOUR SEAT
 
🤓 Improve Manager Effectiveness
 
Join Enboarder, along with our partners ThinkHuman, Bucketlist Rewards, and 15Five for an insightful webinar on "
Leveling Up Your Team: Unlock High Performance through Effective Managers
." In this session, we will explore the vital role that managers play in driving employee success and creating a culture that fosters high performance.
 
Our panel of expert speakers will share practical tips, real-life experiences, and best practices to help managers motivate their teams, set expectations, provide feedback, and leverage tools and techniques to maximize employee performance.
 
Date:
 August 10
Time:
 1:00pm ET / 10:00am PT
SAVE YOUR SEAT
 
This Program has been approved for 1.00 HR (General) recertification credit hours toward aPHR™, aPHRi™, PHR®, PHRca®, SPHR®, GPHR®, PHRi™ and SPHRi™recertification through HR Certification Institute® (HRCI®).
 
This program is valid for 1 PDC for the SHRM-CP® or SHRM-SCP®. For more information about certification or recertification, please visit www.shrmcertification.org.
Hope to see you there!
Stacey @ Enboarder

body:
Time is a precious resource. Learn how to reclaim it and live a happier life. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
BOOKS
COLLECTIONS
TOOLS
CASE STUDIES
HBR STORE
 
 
Are you feeling starved for time?
 
 
You’re not alone. Four out of five adults report feeling that they have too much to do and not enough time to do it. How can we escape the time traps that make us feel this way and keep us from living our best lives?
In 
Time Smart: Tools for Reclaiming Your Time and Living a Happier Life
, you can learn to take back the time you lose to mindless tasks so you can live a happier, more time-affluent life.
 
LEARN MORE
 
 
Within this toolkit you’ll find these valuable resources:
An ebook copy of 
Time Smart
Quick Study Video featuring author Ashley Whillans
Downloadable exercises and strategies described in the book
Additional worksheets and tips to help free up time that you can reinvest in positive, healthy activities
Assessments, checklists, and exercises to support you in achieving the mindset shift that will make time-saving activities part of your everyday regime
Time is a precious resource. This toolkit will help you make the shift to time-smart living and, in the process, build a happier, more fulfilling life. 
 
 
Discover more tools
Find the tools you need to succeed.
 
SHOP NOW

subject: Are you offering the right rewards to middle managers?
body:
Make middle management a destination ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Motivating middle managers
In the news
•
Redefining a role.
 Effective middle managers help companies survive disruption while retaining talent. But without a clearly defined role, they may burn out or default to individual-contributor work rather than leadership work. If that happens, people development could deteriorate. Allowing frontline managers a place in critical decision making could increase their engagement, according to a talent expert. Removing organizational bureaucracy may also help middle managers and their teams thrive. [
Fast Company
]
•
Tight squeeze.
 Middle managers face a tricky balance between carrying out leadership’s directives or implementing new policies and motivating their direct reports. What people want from work (development in addition to flexibility and higher pay) has changed, but managers often don’t have the training or time to deliver these requests. A 2022 study of 20,000 workers found that more than 50% of managers identified as burned out. Executives who provide feedback in the form of coaching—rather than demands—can help managers feel more supported, a senior leader says. [
FT
]
If a person is passionate about their job, then let them stay where they are.
On McKinsey.com
•
The heart of it all.
 Management hierarchies—climbing the ladder through a series of linear promotions—might not appeal to everyone. Not every individual contributor wants to manage people, and not every middle manager desires a corner office. Think of middle managers as the connective tissue between tasks and the people who execute them. Organizations lose valuable employees when they get promoted to positions they don’t enjoy, according to McKinsey partner 
Emily Field
 and colleagues (authors of the new book, ﻿
Power to the Middle: Why Managers Hold the Keys to the Future of Work
).
•
Rethink promotions. 
Many companies are still in the dark about how to promote top performers while keeping them in the same role. Effective organizations, however, recognize the need to reward inspiring middle managers without drastically changing what they love about their jobs. This model works in the trades, where apprentices eventually become masters in their field. Some companies also allow people in technical roles to take a technical-career track, rather than appointing them to lead a team. 
Learn how to retain superstar middle managers
 without promoting them out of the roles that energize them.
Reward managers the right way
— Edited by Gwyn Herbein, editor, Atlanta

subject: Generative AI and the future of work in America
body:
Download the full report ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Since the pandemic, the way we think about work
 has dramatically evolved—remote and hybrid work have become commonplace and companies are quickly adopting automation technologies such as generative AI. Meanwhile, a remarkable number of workers in the US are changing jobs—more than 8 million occupational shifts took place from 2019 through 2022 and an additional 12 million occupational shifts are expected by 2030. How should we make sense of all of this? In a 
new McKinsey Global Institute report
, McKinsey’s 
Kweilin Ellingrud
, 
Saurabh Sanghvi
, Gurneet Singh Dandona, 
Anu Madgavkar
, 
Michael Chui
, 
Olivia White
, and Paige Hasebe explain the forces that are affecting the US labor market, including the potential of generative AI boosting productivity in the US. Be sure to download the full report as you navigate the future of work.
 
Generative AI and the future of work in America
Multiple forces are set to fuel growth in certain occupations and erode jobs in others.
Download the full report  
Quote of the day
“We are placing big bets on AI to help communities solve for some of the big crises many businesses are facing, including understanding and planning for changes in natural disaster patterns, biodiversity, land use, and other geophysical processes.”
—Kareem Yusuf, senior vice president, product management and growth, at IBM, on how energy companies and communities can help solve the net-zero challenge in “
Using digital and AI to meet the energy sector’s net-zero challenge
”
Chart of the day
 
See today’s chart  
ALSO NEW
﻿McKinsey Technology Trends Outlook 2023
Which technology trends matter most for companies in 2023? New analysis by the McKinsey Technology Council highlights the development, possible uses, and industry effects of advanced technologies.
Get up to speed 
 
Setting the revenue cycle up for success in automation and AI
As new technologies emerge, revenue cycle leaders can prepare to harness the potential of these capabilities by establishing the conditions for success today.
Find out how  
Applied AI: Six growth considerations for private markets
As applied AI heats up, we identified key six findings for stakeholders, including investors, to keep in mind as they think about companies in the industry.
Take a thoughtful approach 
 
— Edited by Joyce Yoo
,
 editor, New York

FREE WEBINAR
Welcome to the Revolution: How Ordinary Experts Become Industry Leaders 
Join us Thursday, July 27th at 12:00pm ET
  
Welcome to the revolution.
In the world of professional services marketing, a new movement is replacing the old. We call this movement the rise of the Visible Expert®. Today, prospective clients want to be educated before they buy services, and the thought leaders they learn from become the people and firms they think of first when they are ready to buy. subject: Taking the pulse of US consumers
body:
Key trends in consumer spending ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
﻿The state of US consumers
In the news
•
Pinching pennies.
 US consumers are reining in spending on personal-hygiene products, and that includes everyday basics. From June 2022 to June 2023, consumers bought 3 to 4% fewer units of laundry detergent, toilet paper, and toothpaste, according to the consumer intelligence company NIQ. As shoppers trade down to cheaper brands and products, that could spell pain for retailers and consumer-focused companies that are accustomed to raising prices to cover higher costs. [
Bloomberg
]
•
Summer getaway.
 Travel fares are falling sharply in the US leisure industry, a welcome sign for government officials hoping to cool down inflation without tipping the economy into recession. Airline ticket prices dropped 19% from June 2022 to June 2023, while car rental rates decreased 12%, according to US government data. Demand for travel is still going strong. Roughly six in ten consumers have already traveled for leisure or are planning to do so in 2023, a recent survey of nearly 3,700 US adults found. [
NBC
]
﻿For the first time since the pandemic, the change in real year-over-year spending entered negative territory across all age and income groups.
On McKinsey.com
•
Spending stalls.
 As we head into the summer months, temperatures may be rising across America, but consumer spending is heading in the opposite direction, McKinsey partner 
Kari Alldredge
 and coauthors reveal. In fact, across all age and income groups, consumer spending (as measured by credit card expenditures) is lower than it was a year ago. Although the rate of decline was relatively consistent across demographic groups, low-income consumers showed the steepest drop in spending, at –4.5%.
•
Urge to splurge.
 In April 2023, at least half of Gen Zers and millennials in every income group said that they were planning to splurge. But consumers don’t always do what they intend: real year-over-year spending fell across all income groups that month. Still, some categories seem to be benefiting from the intent to spend freely. Travel was a top category for consumers wanting to splurge in the second quarter of 2023, and travel saw 2% real year-over-year spending growth in April. See our latest research on 
US consumer spending
.
﻿Understand US consumers
— Edited by Belinda Yu, editor, Atlanta

subject: New Privacy Data Settings
body:
Dear Valued Customer,
Zoom will be adding a new setting within the Admin Portal to give you more control over the types of telemetry data Zoom collects to improve our products and services. Starting 
August 19, 2023
, admins and owners can visit the Zoom web portal under Advanced > Privacy to see two new toggles: “Required Service & Diagnostic Data” and “Optional Usage & Diagnostic Data”. Both settings are available at the Account and User Level. 
“Required Service & Diagnostic Data” will be enabled by default and cannot be disabled, as it is data collected by Zoom to operate our service, provide support, improve our product and troubleshoot. The “Optional Usage & Diagnostic Data” collects performance and usage data to provide and improve the performance of Zoom services. Admins and owners will have the option to disable the “Optional Usage & Diagnostic Data” setting if they choose to do so. If this feature is enabled at the account level, users may still disable the “Optional Usage & Diagnostic Data” in the Zoom web portal under Advanced > Privacy. If this setting is disabled at the account level, it cannot be enabled at the user level. Once disabled, Zoom will no longer collect optional data. 
For more information, please reach out to our 
Support Team
. 
Team Zoom 
 
Catch us on social
 
 
 
 
 
Visit 
zoom.us

subject: What it takes to successfully transition out of the CEO role
body:
Embrace what's next ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email

Share this email on

AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Being a CEO is undoubtedly a difficult job,
 but leaving the role can often be even more challenging. Much like a relay race, the goal of the handover is to ensure that the next person is well positioned to perform even better after the baton is handed off. Based on interviews with some of the world’s most well-known chief executives, McKinsey senior partners 
Carolyn Dewar
, 
Scott Keller
, 
Vikram Malhotra
, and 
Kurt Strovink
 suggest four best practices for CEOs who are thinking about the end game: deciding when to go, finishing the job of succession planning, ensuring a clean handoff to the successor, and embracing what’s next. Check out the new 
McKinsey Quarterly
 article
 and see what it takes to achieve a gold-medal-worthy finish to your CEO tenure.
 
Sending it forward: Successfully transitioning out of the CEO role
Great CEOs know that the transition to their successor will define their legacy and cement the strength of what they’ve built. Here’s how they do it right.
Embrace what’s next  
Quote of the day
“As employers, we have to stay constant and continue to grow to ensure our employees are happy because we know that happy employees are healthy employees.”
—
Jo Ann Jenkins, chief executive officer of AARP, on the role of employers in the health and well-being of employees in “
‘Older workers are good for business’: AARP CEO Jo Ann Jenkins
”﻿
Chart of the day
 
See today’s chart  
ALSO NEW
A bigger, bolder vision: How CROs are propelling growth from the C-suite
Chief revenue officers are boosting revenue at not only start-ups but also established companies.
4 traits 
 
﻿
﻿The McKinsey guide to excelling as a CEO
﻿The CEO role is arguably more challenging than it’s ever been. Become the most effective leader you can be with expert insights and advice on topics that should be at the top of your agenda, including gen AI, digital transformations, the changing talent landscape, growth and resilience, the net-zero transition, DEI, and more.
Explore the collection 
﻿

Shape the future 
 
﻿

subject: FW: Last Chance! [Webinar] Conversation Intelligence: Supercharge Your Sales Readiness
body:
Hi Jacob,
Conversations are at the heart of successful sales — but how do you quantify what makes an effective conversation?
Join me Thursday for 
this complimentary webinar
 on the power of conversation intelligence (CI) in enhancing sales readiness. Your host, Jake Miller, senior product marketing manager at Allego, will explain how to identify and model best behaviors across all your sellers, targeting your learning activities to where, and who, it matters most.
In this interactive session, your host will: 
Key factors to identify quality sales conversations without CI
Why CI is critical for understanding the value and efficacy of sales learning programs.
How to uncover competency gaps and take action.
The importance of sharing best practices.
Register now
 for this webinar sponsored by Allego, which airs Thursday, July 27 at 1 p.m. ET.
I hope to see you there! 
Avery Vogt
Webinar Producer | Training Industry, Inc.
 
From:
 TrainingIndustry.com [mailto:info@trainingindustry.com]
Sent:
 Thursday, July 20, 2023 3:06 PM
To: 
Avery at Training Industry <info@trainingindustry.com> 
Subject:
Last Chance! [Webinar] Conversation Intelligence: Supercharge Your Sales Readiness"
Join us for this complimentary webinar.
View this email  in your browser
Moments to Momentum: How to Supercharge Sales Readiness With Conversation Intelligence
 
  
27
JUL
2023
@ 1 p.m. ET
  
Register Now
Traditional sales learning strategies often rely on modeling behaviors from top sellers. However, sometimes the best sellers don't have the best behaviors. In fact, 84% of buyers say reps don’t convey value effectively.
Great sales learning strategies are only as good as the quality of the sales conversations they produce.
By leveraging conversation intelligence (CI), sales leaders get more visibility into these conversations and can easily identify and model best behaviors across all your sellers, targeting your learning activities to where, and who, it matters most.
In this 30-minute live session, Jake Miller, senior product marketing manager at Allego, will cover:
Key factors to identify quality sales conversations without CI.
Why CI is critical for understanding the value and efficacy of sales learning programs.
How to uncover competency gaps and take action.
The importance of sharing best practices.

subject: The Post Most: How right-wing news powers the ‘gold IRA’ industry
body:
Putin appeared paralyzed and unable to act in first hours of rebellion 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

(Sébastien Thibault for The Post)
How right-wing news powers the ‘gold IRA’ industry 
Ads for gold coins have become a mainstay on Fox News, Newsmax and other conservative outlets, even as regulators have accused some companies of defrauding elderly clients. 
By Jeremy B. Merrill and Hanna Kozlowska 
●

Message:
Dear representatives of LCW Inclusion, 
I represent BROS Translation, a Turkey-based company led by 5 in-house project managers & translators and works with 1000+ experienced translators & subtitlers from various countries in 50+ languages. We are currently working with many companies & translation bureaus abroad. Our aim is to provide flawless translations by only NATIVE speakers. 
Our translation bureau is specialized in subtitling, however, we provide translation & interpreting services in other fields as well. We work with experienced and professional native speakers specialized in their respective fields. Since we work with a sufficient number of qualified and skilled translators, we deliver the orders on time. 
Our translators can use CAT tools such as SmartCat, Trados, MemoQ, Memsource and subtitling platforms such as Subtitle Edit, AegiSub, Arctime and any online platform preferred by the client. We will provide the translation file in the required formats. 
Please check out below some of our projects with top clients: 
 Dunes, Paramount, GoTransparent (Turkish-English legal translation) 
 Microsoft Turkey, Turkish subtitles, 2000+ min. 
 REV, Subtitling of videos, Turkish, English, 250+ min. 
 BBO Subtitle, Subtitling of videos, Turkish, 100+ min. 
 WordLights, Subtitling of videos, Turkish, English, Arabic, 500+ min. 
 Appen, Transcription of audio files in Turkish, 200+ min. 
 Day Light, Amara, MateSub, Subtitling of videos, German, English 500+ min. 
 AudioBee, Transcription/Subtitling of audio files in Dutch 300+ min. 
 Collot Baca Subtitling, Exxen, Subtitling Turkish, English 200+ min. 
 Collot Baca Subtitling, Disney+, Subtitling Turkish, English 2000+ min. 
 Dutch subtitles for various websites and YouTube channels 
 Post Haste, The Middle Series, 6 seasons * 20 Episodes, Dutch subtitles 
 Post Haste, various series and movies, 6000 minutes, Dutch subtitles 
Please check out our company profile via our website: www.brostranslation.com 
We can also send our price list for 2023 when asked. 
We are interested in making a partnership with you and cooperate with you in all your Turkish-related and subtitling projects. 
Looking forward to cooperating with you!

subject: Please join the 2024 High Growth Study
body:
Learn how much firms spend on marketing and much more.
 
2024 HIGH GROWTH STUDY
Get a FREE advance copy of the report on your industry (a $799 value)! 
Hi Jacob,
We would like to invite you to join the most comprehensive study of professional services marketing. For the ninth consecutive year, the Hinge Research Institute is conducting the High Growth Study, the largest research study of its kind. 
Whether your firm is a below-average performer or a fast-growing trailblazer, we need your help. 
Click here to take the survey.
We want to help professionals like you understand how firms approach marketing today—and how some professional services firms are able to grow faster, generate more leads, and reap higher profits than their average peers. 
This year’s study will also include several special topic areas, including adoption of ChatGPT, recruiting and retention strategies, approaches to strengthening company culture, and more! 
When you complete the study, you’ll receive these exciting benefits:
Get early access to the study's executive summary
Receive an exclusive code to download your full industry report for free (retails for $799)*
*As soon as it is ready in early 2024
What You'll Learn
We conduct this study each year to help firms in your industry recognize and adapt to a fast-changing marketplace. Here are just a few of the topics we cover:
Buyers’ top business challenges
How much firms spend on marketing
Which marketing techniques high-growth firms in your industry favor
How average- and high-growth firms invest in digital marketing
Practical takeaways you can use to help your firm grow faster and be more profitable 
 
All responses are strictly confidential and will only be reported in aggregate. No responses will be attributed to you or your firm.
Please join us and be part of this important project!
To get started, click 
here
.
Thank you,
Lee Frederiksen, Ph.D.

.

subject: Can traditional companies snag the tech workers needed in the age of AI?
body:
How rewiring HR could help ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Transform HR for better tech talent
In the news
•
Needed: new AI skills.
 AI adoption has renewed interest in established IT skills, but it also requires entirely new ones. Prompt engineers, AI compliance specialists, and AI ethics advisers are roles that didn’t exist until very recently, and there is even demand to add AI-focused roles in the C-suite. Also needed: new security jobs, thanks in part to “shadow IT”—employees’ unapproved use of AI—which exposes companies to new risks. Experts say two elements will set employees up to meet companies’ needs: organizational knowledge, to understand what technologies companies actually require, and a commitment to continuous learning. [
CIO
]
•
Courting tech talent.
 Following layoffs as well as a 33% decrease in job openings in the tech industry in the first three months of 2023, government agencies and a wide range of other employers, including hoteliers, financial institutions, and railroad companies, are snapping up tech workers who were once eager to work only for tech giants. Yet overall, there is still stiff competition for tech talent: the unemployment rate among American tech workers is just 2%. [
AP
]
﻿McKinsey’s research and experience in the tech talent field show that the top 25 to 50 most critical roles can create the bulk of a company’s potential value.
On McKinsey.com
•
Another company’s gain. 
Unlike tech companies, incumbent organizations in other industries have historically had trouble attracting the tech talent they need. This year’s tech industry layoffs create an opportunity for traditional players: McKinsey analysis from the first half of 2023 finds that more than 80% of laid-off tech workers find new jobs within three months, often with nontech companies. An end-to-end approach to HR can help attract—and just as important, retain—tech talent at these organizations, reveal McKinsey senior partner 
Dana Maor
 and coauthors.﻿
•
HR can get you far.
 A holistic HR approach looks at three S’s for improving a company’s tech workforce. For 
sourcing
, identify the roles that create the most value and the skills needed for them, and search beyond the usual suspects both inside and outside the organization. 
Support
 the hiring and onboarding processes with digital tools, and then 
scale
 technology expertise by using digital tools to meet employees’ development needs. See how HR teams in banking, consumer goods, and other industries are improving their ability 
to recruit and retain top tech talent
.
Update HR processes
— Edited by Heather Hanselman, editor, Atlanta
Was this forwarded to you? 
Sign up here
.
Or 
send us feedback
—we’d love to hear from you.
Follow our thinking

privacy policy
.

body:
Get up to speed ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
The promise and potential of generative AI
 has captured the public’s imagination in the first half of 2023, but what other technology trends should be on your radar? McKinsey’s Technology Council has once again identified and assessed the most significant technologies that could transform business and society in McKinsey’s latest 
Technology Trends Outlook
. This year’s trends are grouped into five broader categories—the AI revolution, building the digital future, compute and connectivity frontiers, cutting-edge engineering, and a sustainable world—and each trend includes scores for innovation (based on patents and research) and interest (based on news and web searches). Download the full report, authored by 
Michael Chui
, Mena Issler, 
Roger Roberts
, and 
Lareina Yee
, to understand the potential use cases and the skills needed to capture value from these technologies.
 
McKinsey Technology Trends Outlook 2023
Which technology trends matter most for companies in 2023? New analysis by the McKinsey Technology Council highlights the development, possible uses, and industry effects of advanced technologies.
Get up to speed  
Quote of the day
“Our belief is that by driving digital and financial inclusion we are giving Africans opportunities, dignity, and hope. And the journey we’re going through is then ultimately really about being mission-driven, with people and culture as the most important drivers of success.”
— Ralph Mupita, president and CEO of MTN Group, on the importance of ESG [environmental, social, governance] in “
MTN Group CEO Ralph Mupita: Bridging Africa’s connectivity gap
”
Chart of the day
 
See today’s chart  
ALSO NEW
Higher ed is consolidating, transforming the sector
Enrollment challenges and financial strain are testing the viability of higher education. Strategic alliances offer a path forward, when undertaken with care.
Are you ready? 
 
‘Older workers are good for business’: AARP CEO Jo Ann Jenkins
The head of a renowned organization that advocates for older adults makes the business case for a healthy, happy intergenerational workforce.
Design a new road map  
Using digital and AI to meet the energy sector’s net-zero challenge
Renewable-energy and sustainability leaders from RES, Octopus Energy, and IBM discuss how digital and AI can help drive efficiency, innovation, and collaboration to reach net zero.
Hear from sustainability leaders 
 
— Edited by Joyce Yoo
,

subject: [NEW Webinar] How Ordinary Experts Become Industry Leaders
body:
Raise the visibility of your firm's experts—five times faster than average.
 
FREE WEBINAR
Welcome to the Revolution: How Ordinary Experts Become Industry Leaders 
Join us Thursday, July 27th at 12:00pm ET
  
Welcome to the revolution.
In the world of professional services marketing, a new movement is replacing the old. We call this movement the rise of the Visible Expert®. Today, prospective clients want to be educated before they buy services, and the thought leaders they learn from become the people and firms they think of first when they are ready to buy. This means Visible Experts have a built-in advantage.
Join Hinge’s Lee Frederiksen Ph.D., Liz Harr, and Karl Feldman as they preview their forthcoming book 
The Visible Expert Revolution: How to Turn Ordinary Experts Into Thought Leaders, Rainmakers, and Industry Superstars
. Based on fifteen years of research and hundreds of interviews with top real world experts, this book shares a proven, step-by-step program to raise the visibility of your experts and sharpen their expertise—
five times faster than average
.
Whether you’re a marketing leader looking to make your firm’s experts more visible or an expert yourself who wants to elevate your reputation, this webinar is for you!
   
What You'll Learn:
 
Why Visible Experts are driving the way buyers find, evaluate and select professional services 
The latest research on how Visible Experts rise to prominence 
A step-by-step process to build your expert visibility plan 
How marketing leaders can motivate their experts 
And much more!

subject: Do you know how to create value from generative AI?
body:
Nine actions could help ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Generative AI for CIOs and CTOs﻿
In the news
•
New software.
 With many businesses ready to embrace generative AI, tech companies are capitalizing on the moment. In recent months, multiple US tech corporations have announced the development of a suite of AI tools that will be able to take meeting minutes, evaluate written materials, and generate code. In June 2023, a San Francisco–based cloud computing leader debuted an enterprise software package that offers nine generative-AI-based services. The company charges clients $360,000 per year, on the low end, to use its product. [
NYT
]
•
Who’s in charge.
 For organizations experimenting with generative AI, one question looms large: Who is responsible for leading the way? The technology’s potential to transform processes throughout a company makes it tough to decide, executives explain. Some leaders are enlisting chief technology officers (CTOs) to prioritize AI projects, while others are establishing task forces and new AI-related roles. Earlier in 2023, a US tech company formed a ten-member AI council that includes staffers from its engineering, legal, and marketing divisions. [
WSJ﻿
]
McKinsey research shows generative AI can lift productivity for certain marketing use cases by roughly 10% and customer support by up to 40%.
On McKinsey.com
•
Trillions at stake.
 With its potential to add $2.6 trillion to $4.4 trillion of value annually, the business world’s excitement over generative AI seems well earned, McKinsey senior partner 
Aamer Baig
 and coauthors say. Today’s generative-AI boom offers a unique chance for CIOs and CTOs to guide the C-suite in turning the promise of generative AI into sustainable value for the business. It’s worth remembering, however, that while many companies may experiment with new technologies, creating significant business value is often much harder
.
•
Nine actions.
 To learn how organizations can be successful with generative AI, McKinsey spoke with dozens of tech leaders and analyzed generative-AI initiatives at more than 50 companies, including our own. As more people use generative-AI tools, we have seen some CIOs and CTOs respond by blocking employee access to publicly available applications to limit risk. Such companies, however, may miss out on opportunities to innovate. 
Discover nine actions all tech leaders can take
 to create value, scale solutions, and manage risk for generative AI
.
﻿Get our guide to generative AI
— Edited by Belinda Yu, editor, Atlanta

Sign up here
.
Or 
send us feedback
—we’d love to hear from you.
Follow our thinking

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 July 23, 2023
body:
Last call for magazine proposals, new State of the Industry report and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
To succeed in the world of learning and development (L&D), it’s important to keep up with emerging trends and business practices. That’s why we’re happy to share our latest research report, “
The State of the Sales Training Market
,” where you’ll find all of the key insights you need to gain a competitive edge and stay ahead in the sales market.
We also invite you to download the 
Strategic Planning Toolkit
 to gain access to three helpful templates for aligning training with business goals. Lastly, we’re currently accepting article proposals for the
 2024 Editorial Calendar for Training Industry Magazine
. The deadline to submit an idea is July 31.
As always, we love to hear from you. Please send any comments, suggestions or article pitches to Email 
editor@trainingindustry.com
.
Danielle Murdaugh
Associate Editor
Last Call for Training Industry Magazine Proposals
Do you have an interesting perspective on the current and future state of corporate training? If so, then we want to hear from you! Training Industry is currently accepting article proposals for the 2024 Editorial Calendar for 
Training Industry Magazine
, an award-winning publication that connects L&D professionals with the resources they need to manage the business of learning. We want to hear your insights, strategies and solutions for managing world-class training. Submit your ideas by 
July 31
.
Learn More
 
[State of the Industry Report] The Sales Training Market
Staying up to date on the latest research and trends is time-consuming but essential. Luckily, we’ve done the research and gathered the insights for you in our new report, “
The State of the Sales Training Market
.” In this report, you’ll find all the information you need to gain a competitive edge and stay ahead in the sales market. With data on trends, modalities, market projections, sourcing practices and more, our newly released report on the sales training market has the answers you need.
Get the Report
 
The Roadmap to Strategic Planning
Creating a strategic plan is no easy feat. It doesn’t get easier when you factor in the added layer of challenges that come with L&D, making the proper connections to demonstrate value and communicating why it should matter to stakeholders. But have no fear! We have crafted and packaged the solution for you. Download the
 Strategic Planning Toolkit
 for access to three templates that will help you begin the journey of aligning your L&D function to organizational goals.
Access the Toolkit
 
STRATEGY, ALIGNMENT AND PLANNING 
TICE Takeaway: Why L&D Should Stop Asking for a Seat at the Table
In this article, learning leaders offer their tips for how to be seen as a trusted partner whom stakeholders respect.
Read Now →
MEASUREMENT AND ANALYTICS 
3 Tips for Measuring the Effectiveness of On-the-Job Training
This article provides insightful key tips and tricks to start measuring the success of on-the-job training regardless of the size of your learning function.

subject: ELB Learning Launches Experience Creation Platform, Class Technologies Announces Class 2.0 and Other L&D News ...
body:
Business News This Week
View this email in your browser
July 22, 2023
Industry News from 
Training Industry
Sign up to receive this newsletter each week
 
​​​​​​
ELB Learning Launches Industry-First Learning Experience Creation Platform, the Studio
AMERICAN FORK, Utah — July 17, 2023
ELB Learning, a market leader delivering the most comprehensive suite of learning products and services worldwide, today announced the launch of The Studio: a fully customizable platform for creating and authoring learning experiences.
Read More
​​​​
​​
 
Class Technologies Announces Class 2.0: The Next Generation Virtual Classroom
WASHINGTON — July 19, 2023
Class Technologies Inc., the global leader in virtual classrooms, today announced the upcoming release of its next generation virtual classroom, Class 2.0.
Read More
​​​​​​
PERSONALIZATION AND LEARNING PATHWAYS
Rise Up Releases new Generative AI bot “LIA” to Accelerate Learners’ Time-to-Skill 
LONDON — July 18, 2023
  
Rise Up, the LPI and Fosway recognized blended learning platform, has released new cutting-edge functionality to its LMS/LXP, including a native generative AI bot LIA, to expand their authoring tool by enabling users to create learning content three times faster and a lot more interactive/engaging.
Read More →
IT AND TECHNICAL TRAINING
CompTIA Introduces DataSys+ Program to Expand Data-Related Credentials 
DOWNERS GROVE, Ill. — July 18, 2023
  
CompTIA, the nonprofit association for the information technology (IT) industry and workforce, announced today the release of the CompTIA DataSys+ program, a comprehensive set of resources for learning and skills validation for IT professionals in search of database management skills.
Read More →
CONTENT DEVELOPMENT
Anthology Announces AI-Powered Course Building Tools, New Student Success Features in Blackboard Learn 
BOCA RATON, Fla. — July 18, 2023
  
Anthology, a leading provider of education solutions that support the entire learner lifecycle, announced a host of new features, powered by Artificial Intelligence (AI), designed to help instructors create more engaging learning experiences more quickly and provide granular, easy-to-action insight on learners’ progress.
Read More →
LEARNING TECHNOLOGIES
BetterUp Partners With Microsoft Viva to Drive Peak Performance and Well-Being for Millions in the Workplace 
SAN FRANCISCO — July 18, 2023
  
BetterUp®, the human transformation company, today announced a partnership and integration with Microsoft Viva, the employee experience platform, to bring tools for personalized insights and performance improvement into the workplace.
Read More →
LEADERSHIP
Center for Creative Leadership Partners With Optify to Launch New Coaching Platform to Enhance Leadership Development 
GREENSBORO, N.C. & RESTON, Va. — July 17, 2023
  
The Center for Creative Leadership (CCL)®, a top-ranked global leadership development organization, and Optify, a for-purpose coaching solutions provider re-imagining leadership development with technology, today announced a partnership to launch the new global CCL Coaching Platform, an innovative, integrated web-based platform designed to drive high-value leadership coaching that prioritizes the experience for coaches and coaching participants.
Read More →
MEASUREMENT AND ANALYTICS
Halo Feedback — Global Leader in Enterprise Competency Assessment Technology Announces the Release of Halo Grow 
SYDNEY, Australia — July 17, 2023
  
Halo Feedback, the global leader in enterprise competency assessment technology, is proud to announce the release of Halo Grow – a new, easy-to-use and cost-effective subscription-based assessment offering that is tailored for medium-sized organisations or groups with specific assessment needs.
Read More →

subject: What a new era could mean for Latin America, the value of older adults in the workplace, alliances in higher ed, and more: The Daily Read weekender
body:
Catch up on the week's highlights ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
CURATED PICKS FOR YOUR DOWNTIME, FROM OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
We’ve made it to Friday
 and it’s time to unwind. This weekend, catch up on highlights including what a new era could mean for Latin America, an interview with the head of AARP, strategic alliances in colleges and universities, and more.
 
What could a new era look like for the world—and how will Latin America fare? McKinsey’s Andres Cadena, Olivia White, and Camillo Lamanna explore what a global new era might mean for Latin American economies.
Shape the future
 
Many older adults want to stay in the workforce, according to recent AARP research. McKinsey’s Ellen Feehan talks to Jo Ann Jenkins, chief executive officer of AARP, about the organization’s efforts to communicate the value of older adults in the workplace.
Design a new road map
 
A growing number of higher education institutions are joining forces to develop meaningful alliances. McKinsey’s Jake Bryant, Ryan Golden, and Ian Jefferson share what it takes to get partnerships and M&A right.
Are you ready?
 
﻿Our weekly briefing note on sustainable and inclusive growth explores how cities and buildings can take a hybrid approach, actions for CIOs and CTOs to capture sustainable business value from generative AI, and more.
Get updated
QUOTE OF THE DAY
“To change consumer behavior, we need education in addition to technologies. Democratizing education is key to convincing consumers, for example, to reduce their meat consumption or change their fashion buying patterns. Climate impact and education go hand in hand.”
—Fabian Heilemann, cofounder and CEO of AENU, on the firm’s broad impact investment portfolio in “
A new approach to impact investing from entrepreneur and venture capitalist Fabian Heilemann
”
chart of the day
 
See today’s chart 
Ready to unwind?
What is psychological safety?
Psychological safety is the absence of interpersonal fear. Feeling psychologically safe allows people to perform their best at home, school, and work.
Set the tone
 
Data Points: Your weekly quiz
How well do you know the numbers behind the changes in business, society, and the world? Take the McKinsey weekly quiz to find out.
Take the quiz
 
22-Across: With 27-Across and 25-Down, new book with the subtitle 17-, 46-, and 62-Across
Know the answer? Test yourself with the latest McKinsey Crossword, The McKinsey Crossword: Career Center | No. 137
Empower the manager
 
—Edited by Joyce Yoo, editor, New York

subject: The Big Dirty Secret with Paid Ads 🤐
body:
Social networks will always prioritize users' content over brands’ or sponsors’ content, but we can work with that.
 
 
Hi Jacob!
 
If you’re reading this post, there’s a 99.999% chance that your company is spending a meaningful amount of money on paid digital advertising. Ads.  
 
If we use EveryoneSocial as a proxy, chances are your company spends somewhere between $2,000-5,000/mo per employee on paid ads. That’s a good amount of money. 
In 2023, companies are going to spend more than $65 billion on paid social advertising, such as sponsored posts, follower campaigns, etc. That’s A LOT of money.
 
However, the big dirty secret with paid social is that over time the cost goes up and effectiveness — what your ads produce in return for every dollar spent — goes down.
I repeat: As time passes, social advertising 
costs increase and effectiveness decreases
.
 
Why? Because what’s more important than ad revenue to Facebook, Linkedin, Twitter, and other social networks?
 
USERS.
 
To generate the most revenue from their ad offerings, these networks must 
acquire
 and 
retain
 the greatest possible number of users at all times. Just look at the social platform stock charts. The biggest spikes up/down are always associated with user growth/loss.
 
In other words, users and the content they create are the foundation of any successful social network. They’re its most important asset, which is why all the major social networks 
will 
always
 prioritize users' content 
over brands’ or sponsors’ content.
 
Here’s what Mark Zuckerberg had to say on the topic in 2018:
We built Facebook to help people stay connected and bring us closer together with the people that matter to us. That’s why we’ve always put friends and family at the core of the experience. Research shows that strengthening our relationships improves our well-being and happiness.
 
But recently we’ve gotten feedback from our community that public content — posts from businesses, brands, and media — is crowding out the personal moments that lead us to connect more with each other.
 
Based on this, we’re making a major change to how we build Facebook. I’m changing the goal I give our product teams from focusing on helping you find relevant content to helping you have more meaningful social interactions.
We started making changes in this direction last year, but it will take months for this new focus to make its way through all our products. The first changes you’ll see will be in News Feed, where you can expect to see more from your friends, family, and groups.
 
As we roll this out, you’ll see less public content like posts from businesses, brands, and media.
So, what’s a marketer to do?
We all need to reach prospective buyers, and social media is where they all are. Certainly, we’re not going to stop spending on paid media, but how can a marketer thrive in this reality?
 
In short, by enabling its employees to 
use social media at work
.
 
Giving your people access to an employee advocacy platform such as EveryoneSocial — to share company news, engage with their networks, and grow their personal following — is a fantastic way to turn the social media tables in your favor.
 
After all, in the eyes of social networks, employees are … wait for it… 
users
! Linkedin, Facebook, Twitter, Threads, Instagram, etc., doesn’t distinguish between the personal and the professional you. You’re just you: a person!
 
Let’s take a look at some examples of the results your employees can generate via EveryoneSocial vs. using paid social ads.
 
The leftmost column in the table below outlines top-of-funnel results our clients’ employees generate through EveryoneSocial. By sharing content from our platform to their networks, employees acquire followers, drive clicks, and generate engagement.
 
These are conservative estimates. ☝️ Seriously.
 
If you were to attempt to generate these outcomes by running ads on any major social network  — Facebook, LinkedIn, or Twitter, for example — you’d very likely pay 
a lot
 more than the values shown here.  These are starting floors; e.g., Twitter advises that you budget a 
minimum 
of $3 per follower when running a follower campaign.
 
Conversely, a single active employee on EveryoneSocial produces these same outcomes — by acquiring followers, driving clicks, and generating organic engagements — at a FAR higher quality (remember, they’re people, not brands) and at a fraction of the cost. Literally cents on the dollar.
 
Ready to be blown away?
 
Using the results our clients’ employees created over the first quarter of this year, multiplied by the average costs per outcome outlined in the table above, EveryoneSocial clients were able to generate the following value.
 
 
To reiterate, by empowering their people to promote company news and content, EveryoneSocial clients generated more than $200 million in earned media value over the first half of the year.
 
What’s more, they were able to generate that ROI for less than one-tenth of the cost of paid social.
 
Excited? You should be!
 
Any company can benefit from 
employee advocacy
, and it’s definitely not too late to start. It requires a little time and money, but your investment will build something with lasting value.
 
As always, we’re here if you need us.
 
Thanks for reading, and I hope you have a wonderful weekend!
 
Best,
 
Cameron Brain 
CEO & Co-Founder
EveryoneSocial
 
P.S. - Feel free to connect with me on 
LinkedIn
 or 
Twitter
!
Make sure to follow us on social media!
 
 
 
 
EveryoneSocial, 215 W Sego Lily Dr., #708100, Sandy, Utah 84070, United States

subject: From Gen Z to boomers, are we all really so different at work?
body:
New research reveals what’s myth ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Generation gap
In the news
•
From latchkey kid to leader.
 Boomers are making way for Gen X, the independent-minded cohort born from 1965 to 1980, to start calling the shots. With an average age of 54, newly minted CEOs are supporting more flexible, informal work habits. Given the choice, workers over 55 (boomers, for the most part) would want to spend roughly 35% of their working hours at home; workers in their 20s (Gen Zers) approximately 45%; and workers in their 30s and 40s (including millennials and Gen Xers) 50%, a Stanford University study found. [
NYT
]
•
Don’t ‘circle back.’
 Millennials and Gen Z workers have one request: please stop with the business jargon. Overrelying on idioms such as “herding cats,” “boiling the ocean,” and “out of pocket” are annoying younger colleagues and confusing workers who aren’t native English speakers. This could hamper workplace inclusivity, according to research by LinkedIn and Duolingo. A survey of 8,000 workers in eight countries found that nearly two-thirds of millennials and 60% of Gen Zers long to hear less jargon in the office. [
Fast Company
]
“Gen Z verbalizes everything; they tell you what they want and don’t want. Whereas you have to keep tabs on Gen Xers, because they might be quietly lining up a job elsewhere.”
On McKinsey.com
•
Not so different.
 As multiple generations work side by side at the office, people are paying more attention to age-based differences. New research on generational preferences at work reveals some interesting nuances between different age cohorts, but overall, every generation shares remarkable similarities. At all ages, employees want meaningful work, real connections with coworkers and managers, broader purpose, and fair compensation, partner 
Bryan Hancock
 and McKinsey alumnus 
Bill Schaninger
 explain
.
•
More than a paycheck.
 Because Gen Z talks so openly about compensation, managers might assume that’s all that matters to them, Schaninger says. Although money is a critical factor in younger workers’ employment decisions, it’s not their main priority. In the workplace, Gen Zers are motivated by having flexibility, opportunities for career development, and a supportive work environment, McKinsey analysis finds. 
See how well generational stereotypes stack up
 against our actual research
.
Look before you judge
— Edited by Belinda Yu, editor, Atlanta

—we’d love to hear from you.

subject: Calling all orca whales and human allies: Climate Emergency Day 7/22
body:
Dear Jacob,
Did you know that June 2023 was the 
hottest month ever recorded
? As heat waves, record temperatures, and flash floods sweep the globe, one thing is clear: we are in a climate emergency.
There are numerous ways you can take action against the climate crisis, as we pointed out in our 
Artists Unite for a Green New Deal
 series that we produced way back in 2019. Today, we want to highlight an effort from our friends at the 
Climate Clock
. 
At 12 noon ET on July 22 – the Climate Clock will tick down below 6 years for the first time, Meaning, we will have less than six years to dramatically reduce fossil fuel emissions in order to stay below 1.5ºC degrees warming. This timeline is based on
 IPCC & MCC data
, the gold standards of climate science. 
On July 22, people around the world will mark this moment –
 
Climate Emergency Day
 – with synchronized actions,
 bringing clocks from climate impact zones to the halls of power, demanding that governments and corporations #ActInTime to meet our climate deadline, and enact the real, system-wide solutions we need.
You can participate in many ways. 
Sign up here
Get your own Climate Clock to do a creative action 
Post creative content on social media or send an email blast the moment the clock ticks over - 12pm ET
Amplify your climate related art project on this day
Co-sponsor the day as an organization
To quote activist 
Mariame Kaba
, “Hope is a discipline,” and we hope you will join us in urging governments and corporations to #ActInTime, so that we can maintain hope for a just future.
Pa’lante,
Carol Zou
Secretary of Intentional Community,
U.S. Department of Arts and Culture
Sent via 
ActionNetwork.org
. To update your email address, change your name or address, or to stop receiving emails from U.S. Department of Arts and Culture, please 
click here
.

subject: [NEW Webinar] How Ordinary Experts Become Industry Leaders
body:

FREE WEBINAR
Welcome to the Revolution: How Ordinary Experts Become Industry Leaders 
Join us Thursday, July 27th at 12:00pm ET
  
Welcome to the revolution.
In the world of professional services marketing, a new movement is replacing the old. We call this movement the rise of the Visible Expert®. Today, prospective clients want to be educated before they buy services, and the thought leaders they learn from become the people and firms they think of first when they are ready to buy. This means Visible Experts have a built-in advantage.
Join Hinge’s Lee Frederiksen Ph.D., Liz Harr, and Karl Feldman as they preview their forthcoming book 
The Visible Expert Revolution: How to Turn Ordinary Experts Into Thought Leaders, Rainmakers, and Industry Superstars
. Based on fifteen years of research and hundreds of interviews with top real world experts, this book shares a proven, step-by-step program to raise the visibility of your experts and sharpen their expertise—
five times faster than average
.
Whether you’re a marketing leader looking to make your firm’s experts more visible or an expert yourself who wants to elevate your reputation, this webinar is for you!

Why Visible Experts are driving the way buyers find, evaluate and select professional services
