subject: Language & Culture Worldwide - 2024 From Day One HR/DEI/CPO Leaders
body:
Jake,
 
Excited to share our 2024 calendar of live and virtual people meetings for the HR/DEI and CPO Community.  Please see the press release below but wanted to make sure to bubble this up in your inbox.  Could we set up a call next week to touch base on the calendar and opportunities?
 
How's Friday or Monday? Would 3pm either day work for you?
 
Excited to connect and discuss getting Language & Culture Worldwide involved! 
   
 
Best, 
Missy 
Top executives in HR, Diversity, Corporate Culture, Employee Engagement, and Corporate Social Responsibility discuss hybrid work, social impact, employee engagement, and more
 
 
 
FROM DAY ONE 2024 IN-PERSON CONFERENCE SCHEDULE  
 
 
* indicates exact date is confirmed.
*ATLANTA, GA — January 2
*HOUSTON, TX — February 6
*SEATTLE, WA — February 20
*SILICON VALLEY, CA — February 22
SALT LAKE CITY, UT — March 12
*WASHINGTON, D.C. — March 26
BROOKLYN, NY — April 9
BOSTON, MA — April 18
CHICAGO, IL — April 21
DALLAS, TX — May 7
*MINNEAPOLIS, MN — May 14
 
AUSTIN, TX — June 6
SAN FRANCISCO, CA — June 26
BOSTON, MA — September 12
NASHVILLE, TN — October 1
PHILADELPHIA, PA — October 8 
MANHATTAN, NY — October 22
DENVER, CO — October 29
 
 
LOS ANGELES, CA — November 12
 
 
MIAMI, FL — November 26
 
 
SAN FRANCISCO, CA — December 3
FROM DAY ONE 2023 VIRTUAL CONFERENCE SCHEDULE
Jan. 10, 2024 - 
A Fresh Commitment to a Culture of Well-Being
While many employers recognize the connection between well-being and productivity, creating a healthy balance in the real world of work can be challenging. What are the key choices and thoughtful compromises that must be made for workers to thrive as well as produce? How can managers be trained to make the well-being of their workers a top priority? How can companies get a better sense of which benefits and rewards are most effective–and encourage workers to take advantage of them. 
Feb. 14, 2024 - 
Getting to the Next Stage of Diversity and Belonging 
At a time of resistance and corporate austerity, DEI advocates will need to re-energize themselves and their organizations with new ideas, programs, and reasoning for the cause of diversity. What can DEI practitioners learn from companies with consistent success? How are companies changing their policies to respond to court rulings and lawsuits? What practices have brought the most progress in bringing diversity to leadership rank
 
March 6, 2024 - 
Employee Engagement: Tapping the Secrets of Energizing Workers 
Companies want their employees to be enthused and involved, yet employers need to be thoughtful in fostering these qualities in authentic ways. What’s the latest thinking about how employers can understand the motivations of their workers–and how to respond? What are the best methods for recognizing achievement, both individually and among teams? What’s the connection between engagement and job satisfaction? In the hybrid work environment, what binds workers together and wards off anxiety and loneliness?
 
April 3, 2024 - 
Benefits that Fit Individual Needs Without Busting the Budge
Having made a commitment to recognize the unique needs of individuals, the secret is in the execution. What are the emerging benefits and rewards that workers are seeking, from fertility care to financial wellness? How can companies use technology to stay in close touch with what individuals are experiencing–and where they need help as a result? How can companies choose among myriad point solutions and innovative new platforms? What are the most cost-effective rewards in terms of investments and outcomes
May 22, 2024 - 
The Art and Science of Employee Retention, Coaching and Advancement
While the pace of job-hopping has eased, employers have a powerful motivation to retain skilled workers, both for financial and cultural reasons. How can employers use new tools, including AI, to gain insights about what’s inspiring their workers to stay committed–or walk out the door? Since attrition is often caused by poor relationships with managers, what are innovative ways for employers to train their workers to be better leaders at a time when workers have higher expectations for job satisfaction? How can technology help make coaching more effective?
June 12, 2024 - 
Bringing Talent Acquisition into the Digital Age
Despite layoffs making headlines now, all the demographic and digital trends point toward tough competition for workers in the future–maybe sooner than most expect. What are the new techniques and tools that talent-acquisition can use to envision the workforce their company will need in the future? What data and insights can HR and TA leaders provide to the company to be ahead of trends? How can companies do a better job of internal recruiting and promoting internal mobility? What are the best practices for hiring based on skills and potential, rather than credentials?
 
July 10, 2024 - 
Learning and Development: How New Tools Are Changing Upskilling and Career Mobility 
 
 
As employers put more emphasis on skills as the currency for worker development, they’re seeking new ways to measure them, fill in gaps, and predict the skills needed in the future. How can these new tools, including AI, create better matches between employees and projects? How can employers gain insights from the data they gather? Why do real-world simulations help measure certain skills better than traditional assessments? 
 
July 17, 2024 - 
Innovative Benefits That Support Healthy Families and Caregivers
 
 
As the pandemic’s caregiving crisis showed, employers found significant gaps in their support for the parents and other caregivers in their workforces. The resulting scramble to help has produced a wealth of new HR policies, benefit offerings, and management practices. Where is the greatest demand for support, as well as the most innovative new methods? What have been the most cost-effective ways to help caregivers of all kinds, including parents as well as “sandwich generation” workers caring for elderly and disabled relatives? 
 
Aug. 7, 2024 - 
Employee Engagement: Using Technology to Gain Insight Into Work Needs and Ambitions 
 
Traditional methods like town-hall meetings and surveys can be effective, but data and well-drawn insights can give top leaders a heads up about evolving patterns and trends in their workforces. How can AI and other technology be deployed in a way that brings new insights yet still respects privacy and the individual human factors at play? What approaches will bring employers new empathy for worker needs, ambitions, and well-being? 
 
 
 
Aug. 28, 2024 - 
Pursuing Higher Productivity With Human Factors in Mind
 
 
In a competitive and uncertain climate, most companies need to do more with less. Yet if workers are their greatest asset, employers need to make sure the push for greater output is sustainable. What is the latest thinking about how to measure productivity, the means for stimulating it, and ensuring that workers have the energy to meet their goals–as well as thrive over the long run?
Sept. 18, 2024 - 
Building a Corporate Culture That Workers Can Understand, Influence and Embrace  
Company culture is amorphous yet vital–the shared beliefs, values, traditions and behaviors that drive the actions of individuals and the organization as a whole. Who should be the architects of a company’s culture and how should it be designed and constructed? How should the culture be communicated, broadly and in everyday actions? How should a company start out on a project to evolve its culture in a credible way?  
Oct. 16, 2024 - 
Modernizing Your Workplace for a More Flexible, Inclusive Era
 
 
The arrival of hybrid work sent virtually every employer back to the drawing board about what the workplace should look like, including floor plans, digital platforms, meetings, and even office furniture. After more than three years of experimenting, what have innovative companies discovered about what works–and what doesn’t? How have they improved workplace environments to be healthier, as well as more productive? How have these changes affected the goals of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging?
 
 
Nov. 20, 2024 - 
Finding and Deploying HR Tech That Will Empower Workers  
 
 
The blossoming of innovation in HR technology has given employers untold new abilities to organize, inspire, develop, reward, and care for their workers. Yet this revolution presents new challenges for companies in choosing and supervising these tech tools. How should these tech platforms be evaluated? Which departments of the company should take responsibility–and how can organizations coordinate these moves? How can companies make sure they’re empowering their workers rather than overloading them with adaptation and distraction?
 
 
Dec. 11, 2024 - 
Pioneering Approaches to Digital Transformation and the Future of Work
 
 
The emergence of generative AI in 2023 marked the arrival of a transforming technology that will change human roles, add and subtract jobs, and create astounding new capabilities. How can companies manage the transition, both from the short-term competitive pressures to  long-term corporate survival? How can AI be used to unleash creativity? Where are the areas for abuse, intentional or otherwise? How will digital transformation affect fields from talent acquisition to learning and development? 
 
 
 
 
 
Missy Morrison 
From Day One
www.fromdayone.co

subject: Succeed with your transferable skills, Jake!
body:
Do you know how to use your transferable skills? Transferable skills are invaluable assets that have the power to open doors to diverse care
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Can't see this message? 
View in a browser
 
Hi, 
Jake
!
Edition #7 of the 
Career Well-being Advocate 
newsletter is here!
Do you know how to use your transferable skills?
 
Transferable skills are invaluable assets that have the power to open doors to diverse career opportunities you might not have considered before. In this edition, you'll 
discover and use your transferable skills for job search, career change, and professional development.
 
You don’t need to be a career changer or a job seeker to use your transferable skills in a new job or industry. Professionals seeking career development can also leverage their transferable skills to achieve their career goals. 
 
I didn't share this in the article...
 
How I’ve used my transferable skills to succeed in my career:
 
+ I went from admin to HR.
+ Then, I got into Project Management.
+ HR called me again, and I went back.
+ A few years ago, I decided to become my own boss.
 
I switched careers multiple times by leveraging my transferable skills.
 
Today, as a Career Strategist, I use many transferable skills to serve others.
 
+ Guest speaking at events.
+ Write my own content.
+ Script and film my videos.
+ Help job seekers and professionals develop their careers.
 
Those tasks require:
Communication, problem-solving, adaptability, creativity, emotional intelligence, and more.
 
In this month’s newsletter, I go into detail about the power of transferable skills to help you achieve career success.
 
Click here to read:
 
Unlocking Career Success: The Power of Transferable Skills.
 
Exciting News!!!
 
As you may have noticed, the link to this month's article about 
Transferable Skills
 directs you to my LinkedIn newsletter.
 
WHY?
 
Friend, it's time to share what I've been working on behind the scenes.
 
My website is getting an upgrade, and I'm rebranding!
 
I'll share more details soon.
 
Get ready for more job search and career development content to help you thrive!
Additional Resources 
 
If you need additional information about transferable skills, this article by 
The Muse
 provides examples.
Transferable Skills: The Key to Landing Your Dream Job
 
Read More
This article by 
FlexJobs
 
provides insights into
 
15 Transferable Skills That Companies Want: Examples and Definitions
.
 
Read More
In case you missed it...
Last week, I had the pleasure to co-host another Career Alive event with Career Clarity Coach Theresa White. We discussed, 
The Power of Believing in Yourself.
 It was one of our best live events yet.
 
Watch Here
I recently shared 
this video
 
about career development. Not everyone is a good manager. Find out why!
 
Watch Here
I was honored to contribute to this 
Fast Company
 
article highlighting insights from 17 professionals across various industries, including CEOs, HR directors, and career coaches.
 
How long should you stay at a job?
 
Read More
Jake
, 
I'm grateful to have you as a subscriber, and I am here to help you thrive in your career!
 
Like this newsletter?
 Share this email 
with a friend!
 
Ana

subject: E-commerce can benefit many types of retail businesses. How does your online presence stack up?
body:
Optimize online sales ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Harnessing the power of e-commerce
In the news
•
Right-as-rain supply chains.
 Retailers’ established patterns of predicting customer purchases—which affect ordering, supply chains, and inventory levels—fell apart during the pandemic, resulting in both inventory gluts and shortages. Once stores reopened, customers who depended on buying online in 2020 shifted their spending to travel and other services. Retailers need more agility and flexibility built into their supply chains to keep up with unexpected changes in consumer demand and other shocks, so many are investing in forecasting technology and aiming to recruit data scientists. [
WSJ
]
•
A new lease on life.
 As people move into different homes or remodel an existing space, their tastes and decorative needs may change, sparking a search on an online marketplace or other e-commerce site for just the right table or lamp. Online outlets attracted millions of consumers during the pandemic when brick-and-mortar stores closed their doors. While some buyers thrive on the thrill of the hunt, others may be attracted to an item because of its backstory. When consumers see an item displayed in a staged photo, that heightens their emotions and willingness to purchase it, a marketing professor said. [
NYT
]
McKinsey analysis shows that online sales in US retail jumped 40% year over year in 2021.
On McKinsey.com
•
Mind the (online) store.
 Buying goods online has become second nature to many consumers. In fact, online transactions are expected to account for nearly 25% of all worldwide sales by 2025. Larger retailers that had already invested in capabilities and infrastructure saw a jump in returns during the pandemic, but many small to medium-size companies realize a much smaller portion of revenue from e-commerce, McKinsey senior partner 
Karel Dörner
 and coauthors explain. Guarding against five short-term traps could help smaller retailers grow
.
•
Level up your e-commerce.
 As customer preferences continue to shift postpandemic, companies of all sizes and types can benefit from rethinking their strategies for growth. Channels such as retail media networks and live commerce can help brands and retailers build stronger relationships with customers, while investments in operations (in addition to tech tools) can increase agility and flexibility. Learn how 
e-commerce can generate value
 for a wide range of organizations, including small and large retailers, brands, and consumer-packaged-goods companies
.
Boost online sales
— Edited by Gwyn Herbein, editor, Atlanta
Was this forwarded to you? 
Sign up here
.
Or 
send us feedback
—we’d love to hear from you.
Follow our thinking

subject: What really works when it comes to digital and AI transformations?
body:
Stay nimble ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Most companies are pursuing
 some kind of digital and AI transformation. And while it may be relatively easy for them to define 
what
 needs to happen in such a transformation, it has been much tougher for them to figure out 
how
 to transform and how to make it stick. How can companies move the needle in their digitization efforts, and what does it take to be a leader in this space? In a 
new episode
 of 
The
 
McKinsey Podcast
, McKinsey senior partners 
Eric Lamarre
, 
Kate Smaje
, and 
Rodney Zemmel
 discuss these questions and their new book, 
Rewired: The McKinsey Guide to Outcompeting in the Age of Digital and AI
, which is a how-to manual for companies to succeed in the age of digital and AI. Tune in and see why “it is ‘show me the money’ time for digital transformations.”
 
What really works when it comes to digital and AI transformations?
﻿McKinsey’s 
Rewired
 distills the lessons from successful digital and AI transformations so companies can build competitive advantage.
Stay nimble  
Quote of the day
“As risks have evolved, so too has the need for soft skills, with a risk-focused mindset for flexibility, agility, and speed, to drive our transformation efforts.”
—Roberto Rovere, chief audit officer of BPER Banca, on hiring, training, and retaining the right skill sets within the audit function in “
Innovation drives the internal audit function of the future: Insights from BPER Banca’s chief audit officer
”
Chart of the day
 
See today’s chart  
ALSO NEW
Author Talks: To nurture true potential, reimagine intelligence
A sociologist explores intelligence through the lens of nature versus nurture and takes a closer look at the impact of epigenetics.
Change your perception 
 
A new approach to impact investing from entrepreneur and venture capitalist Fabian Heilemann
﻿The CEO and cofounder of AENU discusses his transition to impact investing and how new structures for impact funds can prioritize high financial returns 
and
 social impact.
Prioritize for impact  
Performance edge: Investors hone their strategies for a new era
Institutional investors are rethinking their strategies across three areas of fundamental importance: purpose, portfolio construction, and proficiency.
Find out now 
 
— Edited by Joyce Yoo
,
 editor, New York

subject: Blueboard Connection | How to impact EX right now
body:
Your monthly round up of tips, strategies, and insights to help you become a most loved employer.
 
 
Elevating moments that matter for your employees.
 
Ok, here’s what we know…
 
Globally, the majority 
(6 in 10) of employees are disengaged
—and that disengagement is 
costly
. Like $8.8 trillion costly 🙈. But! Organizations that prioritize 
investment in employee experience (EX)
 are seeing 
greater workforce productivity
, 
more innovation
, 
more employee resilience
, and stronger overall performance. 
 
Employee experience is the input that drives the outcomes our businesses need to survive and thrive. Which would make investment in EX a perfect solution to widespread disengagement, right? 
 
In theory, absolutely. In practice, it’s a bit more complicated. Because “employee experience” is big. In fact, it’s everything. Gallup defines employee experience as: 
the sum of all interactions an employee has with an employer, from pre-recruitment to post-exit, everything from major milestones and personal relationships to technology use and the physical work environment
.
 
So where do we focus? How do we, as organizational and people leaders, 
decide where to put our dollars
 to have the biggest impact on the employee experience and drive our businesses forward?
 
Investment in employee experience should be ongoing and—ideally—follow guiding principles that are unique to your organization. But, as with anything in business, it’s important to balance short-term and long-term strategies. The reality is most of us can’t wait for slow, large-scale initiatives to kick in; we need to motivate employees yesterday.
 
For organizations looking to make a noticeable impact on the employee experience right now, 
start by elevating the workplace moments that matter.
 
More than 2/3 of working Americans feel underappreciated at work
 but when people 
do
 feel seen and recognized—especially at critical milestones (e.g. after they’ve gone above and beyond, experienced a particular triumph, 
achieved a marquee anniversary
, etc.)—they’re more engaged, loyal, and willing to keep going above and beyond.
 
There’s no doubt that great employee experience is about many things, from offering comprehensive pay and benefits, to how your organization 
connects employees to purpose
, to the processes and systems that support consistent, equitable employer-employee interactions.
 
But 
meaningful employee rewards and recognition
 are a powerful piece of the puzzle because they allow you to nail particularly important moments in the employee lifecycle; and it’s these moments that make up an employee’s experience with your company, these moments that shape employee sentiment, commitment, and discretionary effort.
 
As you look to second half of the year, avoid getting stuck in the “whole” and consider how you can elevate the employee experience in moments and milestones.
 
Be well.
Natasha Wahid
Director of Content
 
Deep dive on a hot topic
 
New research: Employee rewards and the employee experience.
 
Fresh data from The Starr Conspiracy and Blueboard
 reveals that Employee Experience Leaders—companies that place the highest level of importance and investment in employee experience—are focused on strategic employee recognition and rewards. And they’re seeing compound returns on their efforts to elevate the moments that matter.
 
Get the full report to learn:
4 key employee experience indicators you can use to understand your organization’s employee experience “health”
Insight into how EX Leaders invest in employee reward volume and variety
Which types of employee rewards have the most impact on the employee experience
Get the full report
 
 
Featured love letter
 
A candlelit dinner cruise on the Danube, bike tour, and a Hungarian cooking class were the highlights of Eric B.'s Blueboard experience in Budapest! Thanks to Blueboard's Concierge team, this recipient personalized their itinerary to create an experience that was truly unforgettable and tailored to their passions.
Get inspired with more employee #blueboarding experiences on 
Instagram
.
 
 
What we're reading
 
“
How to go the extra mile with mental health support
”
via theHRDIRECTOR
Blueboard’s very own co-founder and president Kevin Yip discusses three steps to help your company prioritize mental health support at work with insights based on the U.S. Surgeon General’s first ever framework outlining policies, processes, and practices to support mental health and well-being in the workplace.
 
“
10 most wanted employee benefits of 2023
”
via EBN
85% of employees are unhappy with work, and in an effort to get to the bottom of why, online job search platform Lensa analyzed Google search data to research the top benefits employees are expecting from their workplaces. The top 3: menopause leave, mental health support, and a 4-day work week. Explore the full findings.
 
“
How to create effective leaders with manager training: A Q&A with Andrea Goodwin, VP of HR at Bridge Home Health and Hospice
”
via the Blueboard Blog
Andrea Goodwin, VP of Human Resources at Bridge Home Health and Hospice, shares lessons from her 25 years in HR in this insightful Q&A. See what specific actions she took to 
boost her organization’s average employee tenure by 75%
, plus how to improve the manager and employee relationship to re-engage staff and increase retention.
 
“
How company culture shapes employee motivation
”
via Harvard Business Review
Why
 we work determines 
how well
 we work. This piece dives into the 6 main reasons people work (play, purpose, potential, emotional pressure, economic pressure, and inertia). The first three motives tend to 
increase
 performance, while the latter three hurt it. Companies with positive, high-performing cultures maximize the good while minimizing the bad.

This will be an interactive exercise where you’ll hear from HR leaders, exchange recommendations, and workshop your recognition ideas on the spot.

subject: Jacob, give your employees access to free 1:1 advising, backed by CollegeVine
body:
New Product Launch: Care for College! 
 
Introducing...Care for College!
Step up your employee benefits by offering your workforce comprehensive and free 1:1 college advising services for their college-bound kids.
Learn more
 
What you get:
 
 
 
What’s included?
Your employees and their dependents can access free advising services and comprehensive resources to help them pick the right school, produce high-quality applications, and navigate the entire college admissions process.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Why should I offer this service?
Helping teens navigate the complexities of getting into college is a full-time job. Working with a college advisor will save your employees hours of time doing personal research while making your benefits program more equitable for employees with older kids.
 
 
 
 
 
 
What is CollegeVine?
CollegeVine is an online platform that offers personalized guidance to help families navigate the college admissions journey by connecting them with a network of professional college advisors and comprehensive resources, including articles, tools, video, live streams, and more.
 
 
 
 
 
 
How do I get started?
Book a demo with a Care representative today.

subject: As people leave urban centers, can superstar cities like London and Paris stay vibrant?
body:
Modeling real estate demand in 2030 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Office space﻿
In the news﻿
•
Cubicle farm.
 You might not expect to see fresh produce growing inside an office tower. But in cities around the world, companies are converting empty office space into vertical farms. In one US building, greens and root vegetables are nestled in conveyor belts that move up and down automatically. The crops travel through varying levels of light and darkness that imitate a plant’s 24-hour cycle. Since office towers are climate-controlled, they are ready-made places for growing food, an urban farming leader says. [
Smithsonian
]﻿
•
Cities’ vacant offices.
 Schools are full of kids, and cruise lines are packed with travelers, but commercial real estate is still wrestling with high vacancies and lackluster demand. In 2026, when a third of US office leases expire, we can expect rents to fall and vacancies to climb higher still. That threatens cities that depend on commercial property taxes for a significant share of revenue. Rather than increase taxes, which might antagonize affluent residents, cities might highlight what they do best: green transit, walkable pathways, and cultural amenities. [
Atlantic
]﻿
Falling demand for office space will drive down value. In the nine cities we studied, a total of $800 billion in value is at stake by 2030.﻿
On McKinsey.com
•
Empty spaces.
 Vacant office and retail space have grown sharply as hybrid work proliferates. Real estate faces tough challenges in the world's superstar cities—places such as Beijing, Houston, and Paris—which claim a disproportionate share of urban GDP and GDP growth. How long could the pain last? To find out, McKinsey modeled several scenarios. In a moderate scenario, demand for office space may fall 13% in 2030, compared with 2019. In a severe scenario, demand could plunge by as much as 38%, explain 
Sven Smit
, McKinsey’s chair of insights and ecosystems and chair of the McKinsey Global Institute, and coauthors.
•
Hybrid places.
 As residents move out of the densest city areas, they’re taking their shopping elsewhere. In metropolitan areas, foot traffic near stores remains 10 to 20% below prepandemic levels. Foot traffic is also recovering faster in the suburbs than in more heavily populated areas. Challenges like these may imperil the fiscal health of cities. Yet they might also prompt a historic transformation of urban spaces. Consider what actions cities, developers, and other stakeholders could take 
to turn empty spaces into hybrid places
.
﻿See our new research
— Edited by Belinda Yu, editor, Atlanta

subject: [Guide] Best Practices for Webinar Surveys
body:
In this guide, we discuss our top tips and best practices for designing and implementing surveys during your webinars and events.
 
 
Best Practices for Webinar and Event Surveys to Maximize 
Data Capture
Download Your Copy
 
One of the primary goals of webinars is to collect data on the attendees, which can be used to better understand their interests, preferences and needs. 
 
Surveys are a highly effective way to collect this data, but they must be designed and executed properly to maximize the amount and quality of data captured. By asking the right set of targeted questions about their experience, opinions, and suggestions, you can gain valuable insights into what worked well and areas for improvement. 
 
This featured guide
 details
 our top tips and best practices for designing and implementing surveys during your webinars and events.
 
Specifically, you'll learn:
Optimal survey structure and language to encourage survey engagement and completion
Recommended question formatting to avoid response bias or skewed data
Incentive strategies to optimize survey response rate
Learn More

subject: Why middle managers should be at the center of an organization
body:
Offer the right rewards ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
What comes to mind when you hear “middle manager”?
 The word “middle” often implies that the person is headed somewhere else—ideally, to the top. But middle management can be a destination rather than a way station, say McKinsey’s 
Emily Field
, 
Bryan Hancock
, and Bill Schaninger, whose new book 
Power to the Middle: Why Managers Hold the Keys to the Future of Work
 comes out today. In a 
new
 
McKinsey Quarterly
 article
 adapted from the book, they explain that middle managers play a critical role of connecting and integrating people and tasks, and should be viewed as being at the 
center
 of an organization—which is why the best middle managers are often best off staying exactly where they are. Abandon the outdated assumptions about the middle layer of management and see why offering the right rewards to your most-valued managers can pay off in the long run.
 
Middle managers are the heart of your company
Stop thinking of middle management as a way station. Instead, make it a destination.
Offer the right rewards  
Quote of the day
“Most of the focus for our customers today is around people and ensuring a people-first digital transformation. And that’s exciting because it’s an opportunity for new technology to really change the game and improve the worker experience.”
—Sanjit Biswas, CEO and co-founder of Samsara, on evolving the company’s value proposition based on shifting customer demands in “
Logistics Disruptors: Samsara’s Sanjit Biswas on scaling real-world impact
”
Chart of the day
 
﻿See today's chart
ALSO NEW
The McKinsey Crossword: Career Center | No. 137
22-Across: With 27-Across and 25-Down, new book with the subtitle 17-, 46-, and 62-Across.
Empower the manager
 
Investing in middle managers pays off—literally
New research shows that having more top-performing middle managers leads to much better financial outcomes. Here are five actions that can set managers and their organizations up for success.
5 actions  
Technology’s generational moment with generative AI: A CIO and CTO guide
CIOs and CTOs can take nine actions to reimagine business and technology with generative AI.
Harness the power 
 
— Edited by Joyce Yoo
,
 editor, New York

subject: Join us July 25th for our Mental Health 101 live webinar!
body:
Learn how to address mental well-being for your employees. Register for our free webinar to learn more. 
 
Hi Jacob,
 
As the first line of defense against toxic work environments, managers are now expected to be able to start meaningful discussions about mental health and connect their employees with the support they need.
 
During this webinar, we will give you the proper tools and resources in order to identify and support the needs of your team. You’ll learn: 
Common mental health symptoms
Signs and symptoms of someone struggling with a mental health challenge
How to start and continue the conversation about mental health concerns
Practical ways to encourage employees towards self-care and professional support 
Join us on Tuesday, July 25th, at 2 p.m. EST for this free webinar hosted by

subject: 💥 Performance Review Best Practices, AI & HR Webinar, Career Development, & More!
body:
Actionable tools, industry trends, upcoming events, research, and more delivered to your inbox monthly.
 
 
 
What if you knew a way to quickly and painlessly improve your company's performance assessment process? Last month in Culture Club we dispelled the myths and shared the science behind the most effective performance reviews.
 
Watch a replay of our 
Performance Reviews
 mini-workshop, to learn how to:
Crowdsource performance review best practices from a wide range of companies
Leave with a framework to assess the quality of your own reviews and a list of new ideas to implement
 
Want to improve your company's performance assessment process?
Talk with a LifeLabs Consultant
 
 
An important paradigm shift is happening in the purpose and process of performance reviews. For a long time, the primary goal of performance assessment was correction. Set performance standards → measure past performance against those standards → correct (or reward) performance. In this sense, performance and professional development were seen as one in the same. The only development that was deemed relevant was closing gaps in current performance to achieve current goals.
 
Today, companies 
and
 employees are recognizing that this Performance = Development approach is letting us all down.
 
But divorcing performance from development entirely doesn’t help either.
When performance and development are separated, employees develop skills that aren't valued by their companies, causing inefficiency and frustration.
 
The most successful and nimble organizations now take a Performance + Development approach. 
These companies create systems to ensure that employees are supported in achieving high performance today while also developing high leverage skills for the future. At LifeLabs Learning, we refer to high leverage skills as the skills that lie at the intersection of capabilities that companies need now and in the future + the skills that employees find personally rewarding and motivating to attain. 
 
Continue reading to learn how to integrate development into your performance reviews.
Read more
 
Keep learning with our 
Performance Review Playbook
:
a guide to help managers 
People Ops Leaders build or revamp their performance review systems.
 
Do you have a LifeLabs experience you'd like to share with the world? We'd love to hear from you! Simply answer a few quick questions, send us your headshot, and share your testimonial to be 
featured on our website
. Let your story inspire others and make a lasting impact.
 
I'm in!
 
 
Culture Club Seattle: Career Growth
 
July 18, 5:30 PM - 8:00 PM PT
 
Hey there, Seattle! 🏙️Culture Club is returning! Get ready to join in on the fun and connect (
yes, in-person!
) with other awesome HR and People Ops leaders in the Seattle area. We'll share helpful tools, frameworks, and experiments that you can start using right away to enhance the growth culture and systems at your company. Don't miss out on this one-of-a-kind opportunity to network and learn!
The Impact of AI on HR
 
July 20, 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM ET
 
Calling all HR and People Ops professionals: how do you feel about Artificial Intelligence (AI) and what it means for the HR profession and employee experience? If these emojis capture your emotions 🤯😱🤓🤩, then we have an event for you! Join us for a virtual discussion about emerging trends in AI and their implications for HR and People Ops leaders. This virtual panel is open to HR professionals, leaders, and enthusiasts from all industries. No prior knowledge of AI technologies is required!
Culture Club Los Angeles: Career Growth
 
July 20, 5:30 PM - 8:00 PM PT
 
📣 Attention all People Ops/HR professionals in Los Angeles – mark your calendar because 
Culture Club is coming back to LA! 
Join us at Culture Club, in person, for an evening of skill-building, idea-sharing, and networking with other HR and People Ops professionals in the LA area. We'll share tools, frameworks, and experiments you can immediately use at your company to deepen your career growth culture and systems. 
Culture Club Virtual: Career Growth
 
July 25, 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM ET
 
Employees crave growth, managers want their direct reports to grow, and companies need skilled, inspired employees. Yet catalyzing the desired career growth remains challenging. In this mini-workshop by LifeLabs Learning, we'll share tools, frameworks, and experiments you can immediately use at your company to deepen your career growth culture and systems. 
Save your seat, o
ne session left!
Explore all upcoming LifeLabs Learning events!
 
 
Accountant (Remote)
We’re looking for a data-loving efficiency builder. Could that be you?
 
As our

subject: Improving workforce participation for intersectional workers requires targeted action
body:
Which UK workers are furthest behind ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
﻿Creating opportunities for UK minorities
In the news﻿
•
Wage inequality, meet pay transparency.
 According to data from the European Institute for Gender Equality, closing the gender employment gap could lead to between 3.5 million and 6.0 million new jobs being created by 2050. Wage transparency reporting is one tool countries are using to increase awareness of the issue. Since 2018, companies in the UK with more than 250 employees have reported average wage differences between men and women (based on a rough measure of what men and women earn on average across the workforce), while other countries allow workers to request comparable data. [
WaPo
]﻿
•
Underrepresented in retail.
 Even though women make up more than 50% of the UK retail workforce (one of the nation’s largest industries), a new report shows they remain underrepresented in leadership roles. New data from a survey of more than 200 businesses reveals that only 41 boast female CEOs or CFOs, while just 13 have female chairs. In addition to the lack of gender diversity, businesses also lack racial diversity in the top ranks: about one-third of boards are made up of only White members. [
Bloomberg
]﻿
Our analysis shows that closing the pay gap could translate to a 30% increase in the average Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani woman’s annual salary.﻿
On McKinsey.com
•
Falling behind.
 UK workers who identify as Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani are the furthest behind on pay and labor force participation, and those who fall at the intersection of gender and ethnicity are particularly vulnerable. Compared with all other ethnicity and gender combinations, Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani women are at the greatest disadvantage, McKinsey senior partner 
Tania Holt
 and colleagues reveal. While more women in these groups aged 16 to 25 are furthering their education and starting careers in higher-paying jobs, Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani women aged 26 and older face a growing disparity in pay as they continue their careers, due in part to an underrepresentation in leadership positions
.
•
For the good of all.
 Improving women’s earning potential translates to economic gains that benefit entire communities. But closing the pay gap for Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani women requires targeted effort on the part of employers, starting from an understanding of the economic and cultural experiences of these groups. Recruiting initiatives, professional network building, and transparency in the promotion pipeline could directly improve Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani women’s experiences in their organizations. Consider 
four meaningful actions leaders can take
 to address racial equality at work
.
﻿Advance intersectional workers
— Edited by Gwyn Herbein, editor, Atlanta

.

send us feedback
—we’d love to hear from you.

AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Since the beginning of the pandemic,
 our relationship with office spaces has dramatically changed. Hybrid work has become the new normal for many—and it is here to stay. So what’s next for office, residential, and retail spaces in major cities? In a 
new McKinsey Global Institute report
, McKinsey’s 
Jan Mischke
, Ryan Luby, Brian Vickery, 
Jonathan Woetzel
, 
Olivia White
, 
Aditya Sanghvi
, Jinnie Rhee, Anna Fu, 
Rob Palter
, 
André Dua
, and 
Sven Smit
 take a deep dive into the pandemic’s lasting impact on real estate and the ripple effect of hybrid work on where people live and where they shop. Give it a read and see what it takes to thrive in hybrid spaces.
 
Empty spaces and hybrid places: The pandemic’s lasting impact on real estate
Real estate in the world’s superstar cities has not kept up with shifts in behavior caused by the pandemic. The cities’ vibrancy is at risk, and they will have to adapt.
﻿Explore the full report
Quote of the day
“We have the potential to seize the learning moment in our environments. No matter how neurotypical or neurodivergent we seem, we are doing that. That’s the natural ability we learn from our environments.”
—Genetics expert and associate professor of sociology at Rutgers University Rina Bliss on seeing the infinite ability of all humans in a 
recent 
Author Talks
 interview

See today’s chart
ALSO NEW
Bolstering health system supply chain resilience to reduce risk
How health systems could enhance their ability to withstand supply shocks and deliver quality care in ordinary times and when crises strike.
4 steps 
 
High hopes despite high prices: An update on European consumer sentiment
Consumer confidence has grown dramatically across the continent—but geopolitical concerns and price increases continue to affect how consumers intend to spend. ConsumerWise offers its latest research.
5 charts

subject: A call to move beyond Land Acknowledgement
body:
Dear Jacob,
So much gratitude from the bottom of our hearts to all of you who showed up for our online concert commemorating USDAC’s 
Honor Native Land
 project, and a big shoutout to performers 
Frank Waln
 and 
Pura Fe
 for gracing us with a special set and a special Q&A. We hope that you left this network gathering feeling inspired to renew your commitment to learning about and supporting Indigenous sovereignty.
If you missed our Network Gathering, you can access the recording 
here
. We urge you to take Pura Fe’s words to heart and truly learn about the issues facing native communities as the step to moving beyond just Land Acknowledgement.
If you have any questions about the future of our Honor Native Land program, please read our statement

subject: Re: Strategy and 2024 budget opportunities
body:
for what its worth, when I first took over Diversity Best Practices, the organization had a 33% attrition rate.  We were down to 120 Fortune 500 companies. 
I asked myself what would I want from a DEI advisor/consultancy. I came up with 3 things that became our focal point:
scalable, actionable and relevant tools 
thought leadership
personal relationship I could trust
As a result I had my team (two of us at the time-- me and 1 other) create just in time materials to help business leaders address hot topic issues as they arose or that we predicted.  This was not so much a declaration of what we could do or what our capabilities were but tools they could replicate and scale for their use.
e.g. what do I say when employees ask what our position is on affirmative action? what can we do to support employees that may be impacted by this ruling?  what can be done to support our marketplaces and communities that are we play in, that may be impacted by this ruling?  
 
what should my organization do to counteract the ruling? 
 how can we learn from this...what proactive actions should we be taking in order to advocate and champion our perspective (be authentic champions v performative/reactive)
what best practices are we seeing other organizations taking to make a difference in the wake of the ruling (or proactively)
we then turned these into webinars...
just sharing a couple of examples.  
the turbulent times was more reactive in 2016
the maintaining social cohesion was proactive.  we issued that in April after initial covid reports and lock downs in feb/march in the US
deb

Subject:
 RE: Strategy and 2024 budget opportunities
 
With regards to the affirmative action issue…thank you for highlighting it, I know that Camille and Lukeisha (my two top clients) will be asking me soon about our position and for talking points.
 
It is my view that – in terms of products and services -- our culture-first approach is the way forward, and the way 
through
 these changes in our country’s legal landscape. I think we need to work on a podcast, blog article, or social media post (or something!) that we can use to state our position, which is something like “no matter what the government says about affirmative action (or “wokeness,” for that matter) we are here to help you create a sustainable culture of inclusion in this culturally diverse world, because we know that it’s the way to achieve your goals as an organization.”
 
Happy to take the lead on that if folks think it will be useful.

Subject:
 Strategy and 2024 budget opportunities
 
Hi Everyone,
For some of my clients, it is beginning to be the time of year to consider 2024.  I am looking for help responding to the following areas of interest.  What do/can we offer, how might I respond.  And finally, who could help me with the approach to create a journey…
 
PING
:  “
I've been asked to explore availability of any 
training, resources or other tools for US based leaders who manage employees in other countries (primarily India).
 We have an office in India that is growing and will continue to do so.
 
I checked your website and it looks like these are offerings which I assume helps address this concern.  Cultural literacy
Cultural immersion series (facilitated)
Navigating global cultures (facilitated)
Culture and Identity (e-learning)
Are there any other resources (or tools) that are available from a best practice perspective?”
 
Aflac
:  
Due to the recent attention on Affirmative Action, etc., I am keeping an eye out for any developments. Would like to double down on training efforts for our HR teams.  Do you have any specific training offering for hiring practices/diverse hiring etc?  Would love to see what you offer.  We have around 100 people in HR.
 
Collective help is really needed.  I am thinking that with our India trainers, we might have more flexibility proposing more of our standard catalogue, because I assume it will be shared in a culturally competent way.  Is that a true statement.
 
And for the issues of Affirmative Action issue influencing Aflac (and other companies)  what would we propose for enhancing the learning.  Does anyone have ideas about the opportunity for out trainings in the face of these issues??
 
Wished I had sent this before our Monday meeting.  I need to get back to clients next week.  Please send your ideas or let me know if you are interested in a discussion.
 
Thank you all.
 
Cheers~
 
Andrea Wicks Bowles
(She/Her/Hers)
Senior COnsultant

subject: Auto companies need tech workers. What will it take to attract them?
body:
What US tech workers desire ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Carmakers’ race for tech talent
In the news
•
Finding factory workers.
 The electric-car industry is the focus of American ambition to jump-start domestic manufacturing and become a leader in critical technologies. But even as new factories are popping up across the country, the US confronts a shortage of experienced workers. Vocational schools that partner with auto brands may provide part of the answer. One system of technical colleges in Tennessee has 34,000 students attending; in 2017, the school teamed up with a Japanese electric-vehicle (EV) maker to establish a new campus. [
Bloomberg
]
•
Teenage trainees.
 The EV revolution is here. There’s just one problem: countries need many more skilled workers to produce EV batteries. Throughout Asia, Europe, and North America, many leaders are grappling with the same issue—how to train and recruit battery engineers, technicians, and others needed for the energy transition. One Asian country is enlisting teenagers and trade school students to study battery technology; it aspires to add 30,000 more workers to the battery industry by 2030. [
Quartz
]
Survey respondents indicate that having caring and inspiring leaders is a top ten factor for staying in or leaving a role and an important reason for accepting a new job.
﻿On McKinsey.com
•
Vital skills.
 Auto and mobility leaders face significant skills gaps. But despite recent shake-ups, tech workers are scrutinizing potential employers. What matters most to this crucial part of the workforce? A McKinsey survey of about 1,500 US tech workers finds that career development is the most frequently cited reason for employment-related decisions, with 43% of respondents reporting it as a top factor for why they stay in a current job, accept a new role, or leave one, McKinsey partner 
Asad Husain
 and coauthors explain
.
•
Attracting talent.
 Seven of ten automotive leaders are focusing on building new businesses, previous McKinsey research has shown. Automotive and mobility incumbents now have a chance to snap up tech talent in what could be a singular realignment. However, that will require effectively outlining the expectations and commitments of the worker–employer relationship. See four dimensions of an effective employee value proposition that 
auto and mobility leaders can consider as they seek to attract and retain critical tech workers
.
Learn what motivates tech workers
— Edited by Belinda Yu, editor, Atlanta

—we’d love to hear from you.

THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
Today’s business landscape is changing — fast. Technologies that may have seemed novel just a few years ago are now par for the course, and advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) continue to make waves across industries.
Training Industry is dedicated to putting out timely resources that can help you deliver impactful training that will position your organization for success in an uncertain future of work.

Sarah Gallo, CPTM

subject: [QuickMail] exclusive deliverability stats :)
body:
the best day to send emails for replies and the one you should avoid because of high unsubscribes
Oh YES! I have new stats I can share with you.
Why am I sending this newsletter on a Sunday? Read on, all will be explained :)
And please allow me to geek out, I promise this will be worth it!
You might already know it, but we rolled out our advanced stats analytics about a month ago in QuickMail.
Since then, it's been recording silently how well each email was sent and opened with proper day attribution.
What's Day attribution? Instead of learning what day most emails are opened, I'm going to share with you the days it's better to
 *send*
 the emails to 
get more opens/replies/clicks
.
This gives us beautiful insights into when we should be sending our emails (not when it gets open, which we have no control over. Big difference).
What day do you think is the best one for optimizing opens?
or minimizing unsubscribes?
Well, when it comes to maximizing views, the weekend is your best choice
 by far
.
Together, Saturdays and Sundays were responsible 
for 1/3rd!! of all the opens
 detected on the system, with Sunday responsible for 18.66% of all generated opens on its own.
Weekends clearly outperform all the other days of the week by a large margin.
Opens rate:
Days emails generating opens were sent:
Sunday: 18.66%
Saturday: 16.92%
Tuesday: 13.43%
Monday: 13.1%
Wednesday: 12.85%
Friday: 12.67%
Thursday: 12.37%
Given these, you may be tempted to maximize sending on Saturday and Sunday, but know that we want people to actually 
take action
 (reply or click on links) not just read their emails.
Click rate:
Days emails generating clicks were sent:
Saturday: 16.9%
Monday: 15.1%
Friday: 15.07%
Wednesday: 14.05%
Thursday: 13.84%
Tuesday: 13.71%
Sunday: 11.33%
Look at how poor Sunday is for clicks! Sunday was only responsible for 11.33% of total clicks detected, compared to 16.9% on Saturday.
People who open emails sent on Sunday don't really want to engage in research/checking what this is about really.
Emails sent on Saturday generate more clicks.
Cool, but what about replies?
Reply rate:
Days emails generating replies were sent:
Sunday: 15.48%
Tuesday: 15.17%
Wednesday: 15.17%
Monday: 14.11%
Thursday: 13.51%
Saturday: 13.35%
Friday: 13.20%
Replies are clearly indicating that it's bad to send emails toward the end of the week, with Thursday, Friday & Saturday performing poorly. Don't you dare send cold emails on a Friday if you want an answer :)
We also learn that people are open for business for emails sent on Sunday! Sending on Sunday will get you the best visibility and best reply rate but don't expect clicks.
This may be a day when people try to quickly clean up their inbox before going to work on Monday.
Unsubscribe rate
I can explain previous stats but the truly shocking one is unsubscribes…
Days emails generating unsubscribes were sent:
Thursday: 30%
Tuesday: 16.48%
Wednesday: 12%
Monday: 11.6%
Friday: 10.78%
Satursday: 10.48%
Sunday: 8.65%
WOW, look at the difference between sending email on Thursday vs Sunday!
Almost a THIRD
 of the unsubscribes are coming from emails sent on Thursday! WTF? 
I have no idea why Thursday would lead to so many unsubscribes but if you have a theory, I'd love to hear it.
Conclusion
It looks like sending cold emails past Wednesday is a bad idea. It may be best to wait Sunday to start that new campaign after all :)
It certainly won't compensate for a bad copy, but it may give you an edge as you increase your odds of success.
Future?
Now we have AI, we'll start tracking if people answering emails sent on Sundays are more inclined to reply positively or negatively. I'm super curious about this.
After all, positive replies are what we are after. Are there days when people are more in the mood to reply positively?
Plus, I'll provide information on how long it takes people to reply on average so you can optimize wait time between emails to maximize awareness without being too pushy and rubbing some feathers.
SubCampaigns & AI
We finally rolled out SubCampaigns in QuickMail for every reply type we support with AI detection as well as Out of Office detection.
Want to send a follow-up email asking them how their time out of the office went to get more replies? It's now possible.
Head over to your account settings (Settings / Replies) and select the campaign to send (make sure your campaign starts with a Wait step so you don't send the email immediately)
Got AI activated for your account? You are in luck.
No need to waste time to execute all the requests for unsubscribes, the AI automatically detects a request for unsubscribe and sets the prospect as Do Not Contact.
It won't even create an opportunity. No time wasted. Pretty neat.
Finally, you can extend the idea to pretty much all replies. Head over to your campaign settings and configure the AI to automatically start a campaign base on the reply type detected.
It will skip the creation of an opportunity and start automatically the prospect on the new campaign.
Podcast: Re-Engaging Your Prospects After Two Years?
How much later is it still ok to re-engage prospects? Apparently, even after two years.
In this week's episode, we tear down an Appsumo re-engagement campaign and highlight what's bad, what's good, and what could be much better.
Teardowns are 
packed
 with actionable tips you can apply to your campaigns right away to get better results from your outreach.
Don't miss it -> 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LFESO0iCCJ0
Want us to cover a specific topic? Shoot your idea over at 
podcast@quickmail.io
Tool of the week: Slite
Looking for a Notion alternative that gives you easy access to your team's knowledge base
? Check out 
Slite
.
Slite is a modern workspace that helps teams escape the chaos of information overload. It combines intuitive documents with async decision-making, enables teams to bring clarity to their work, and helps to take the pain out of finding info and learning from the past with it's AI assistant.
Found a great tool that isn't known enough? Hit reply and let me know.
That's it for today.
Be amazing,
Jeremy

here
.

subject: iSpring Unveils Course Portfolio, OpenSesame Launches AI Assistant and Other L&D News ...
body:
Business News This Week
View this email in your browser
July 15, 2023
Industry News from 
Training Industry
Sign up to receive this newsletter each week
 
 
iSpring’s Game-Changing Course Portfolio for Suite Max & Page
ALEXANDRIA, Va. — July 13, 2023
iSpring Solutions, Inc., a global leader in eLearning software and services, unveiled the release of Course Portfolio, the new functionality to showcase accomplished eLearning projects to the public. This update will provide both emerging and seasoned Instructional Designers with an opportunity to create, store, and showcase their best works on the same platform.
Read More
 
OpenSesame Revolutionizes Inclusive Learning at Scale for Global Workforces With the Launch of Simon
PORTLAND, Ore. — July 11, 2023
OpenSesame, the business training platform for L&D professionals seeking innovative solutions and world-class courses, is proud to announce the launch of Simon, a first-of-its-kind course creation and translation platform. The launch of Simon marks the beginning of a new chapter for the elearning industry. Organizations who do not have the time or money to invest in language translations for multilingual staff are now able to develop high-quality courses quickly and translate them just as easily with this powerful course creation platform.
Read More
IT AND TECHNICAL TRAINING
Skillsoft Expands Technology Skilling Solution as 80% of C-Suite IT Leaders Report Workforce Skills Gaps 
DENVER — July 12, 2023
  
Skillsoft (NYSE: SKIL), a leading platform for transformative learning experiences, today announced significant enhancements to its technology skilling solution, now branded as Codecademy.
Read More →
LEARNING TECHNOLOGIES
Wipro Launches Wipro ai360, Commits to Investing $1 Billion in AI Over the Next Three Years 
EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J. & BENGALURU, India — July 11, 2023
  
Wipro Limited (NYSE: WIT, BSE: 507685, NSE: WIPRO), a leading technology services and consulting company, today announced the launch of Wipro ai360, a comprehensive, AI-first innovation ecosystem that builds on Wipro’s decade-long investments in artificial intelligence (AI) with the goal of integrating AI into every platform, every tool, and every solution used internally and offered to clients.
Read More →
SALES
SBI Acquires Sales Readiness Group 
DALLAS — July 10, 2023
  
SBI, a go-to-market growth advisory, today announced the acquisition of Sales Readiness Group (SRG), an industry-leading sales training company. 
Read More →
LEARNING TECHNOLOGIES
Administrate, an Enterprise Training Operations Platform, Raises $6.4M to Automate and Solve Complex Training Logistics 
BOZEMAN, Montana, — July 11, 2023
  
Administrate, the leading enterprise training operations platform, announced today that it had raised $6.4 million from existing investors Archangels, Mercia, and the Scottish Investment Bank, and that it had welcomed Hambro Perks as a new capital partner.
Read More →
MEASUREMENT AND ANALYTICS
ACI Learning Launches Proprietary AI-Powered Skills Gap Analysis Tool 
DENVER — July 13, 2023
  
ACI Learning, the audit, cybersecurity and IT training leader, today launched Insights, a skills gap analysis tool for team leaders to continuously address staff knowledge gaps.
Read More →
SALES
Truelink Capital Acquires Richardson Sales Performance 
LOS ANGELES & PHILADELPHIA — July 10, 2023
  
Truelink Capital (“Truelink”) today announced its acquisition of Richardson Sales Performance.

Compete in an AI world
 
Leading economists and business experts predict that AI will completely transform how we live and work. How will AI impact your industry, company, and career? Get up to speed on the latest research and intel with HBR’s 
Artificial Intelligence Library: How to Remain Competitive in an AI World
. 
 
LEARN MORE
 
 
 
This specially priced 7-volume set includes:
 
 
Competing in the Age of AI: Strategy and Leadership When Algorithms and Networks Run the World
 
Packed with examples, many from the most powerful and innovative global AI-driven competitors and based on research in hundreds of firms across many sectors, this is your essential guide for rethinking how your firm competes and operates in the AI era.
 
 
 
 
 
Human + Machine: Reimagining Work in the Age of AI
 
In this much-needed management playbook, you’ll discover how to become an AI-fueled business so you can leap ahead on innovation and profitability.
 
 
 
 
 
Prediction Machines: The Simple Economics of Artificial Intelligence
 
Economists explain the profound impact of AI and how CEOs, managers, policy makers, investors and entrepreneurs can navigate the changes on the horizon.
 
 
 
 
 
HBR’s 10 Must Reads on AI, Analytics, and the New Machine Age
 
Contains the most important HBR articles to help you understand how these technologies work together, how to adopt them, and why your strategy can’t ignore them.
 
 
 
 
 
All-in On AI: How Smart Companies Win Big with Artificial Intelligence
 
Get a rare inside look at what the leading AI adopters are doing, while providing you with the tools to put AI at the core of everything you do.
 
 
 
 
 
Power and Prediction: The Disruptive Economics of Artificial Intelligence
 
When prediction is taken to the max, industries transform, and with such transformation comes disruption. Learn what’s at the root of this and how we can make the coming AI disruption work for us, not against us.
 
 
 
 
 
Artificial Intelligence: Tools for Preparing Your Team for the Future
 
Includes a step-by-step training guide, comprehensive slide deck, case studies, and thought-provoking questions to help stimulate team thinking and kick off the discussions needed to move your company forward.
 
 
Learn what it takes to successfully compete in the AI world. This specially priced 7-item digital library is a must-have for anyone who needs to recognize the potential impact of AI, how it is driving future growth, and how they can compete.

CURATED PICKS FOR YOUR DOWNTIME, FROM OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Finally, it’s the weekend,
 and it’s time to dive into some of the week’s highlights including the latest on consumer sentiment in Europe, Africa’s potential, reimagining intelligence, and more.
 
What’s consumer sentiment like in France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the UK? Check out the latest research survey by McKinsey’s Jessica Moulton, Thomas Rüdiger Smith, and their coauthors.
5 Charts
 
University of Cape Town professor Carlos Lopes talks about seizing Africa’s potential in a new episode of MGI’s 
Forward Thinking
 podcast.
Get perspective
 
In a new 
Author Talks
 interview, genetics expert and sociologist Dr. Rina Bliss explains why environments, not genetics, are the source of human intelligence.
Change your perception
 
Our weekly briefing note on sustainable and inclusive growth explores the need for a retail reset, how generative AI can help streamline routine healthcare tasks, and more.
Get updated
QUOTE OF THE DAY
“The ability to extract full potential value from digital solutions is the key to successful long-term transformations. Rewired companies achieve this outcome by building a culture of continuous growth driven by scaling and supported by reinforcing mechanisms.”
—See how rewired companies focus on scaling through a modern culture in “
The rewired enterprise: How five companies built to outcompete
”
chart of the day
 
See today’s chart 
Ready to unwind?
What is digital-twin technology?
A digital twin is a digital representation of a physical object, person, or process, contextualized in a digital version of its environment. Digital twins can help an organization simulate real situations and their outcomes, ultimately allowing it to make better decisions.
Simulate reality
 
﻿
Data Points: Your weekly quiz
How well do you know the numbers behind the changes in business, society, and the world? Take the McKinsey weekly quiz to find out.
Take the quiz
 
52-Across: Devil Dogs, Yodels, and Ring Dings, e.g.
Know the answer? Test yourself with the latest McKinsey Crossword, Possessive Rhymes | No. 136
Rhyme or reason
 
—Edited by Joyce Yoo, editor, New York

subject: Accepted: Alisa/Jake Last Day Check-In
The #1 Reason to Invest in Advocacy 👉
body:
If there's a single reason to invest in employee advocacy, this is it: Social networks will ALWAYS prioritize users over brands.
 
 
Hi Jacob!
 
If there's a single reason to invest in employee advocacy,
 
this is it: Social networks will ALWAYS prioritize users over brands.
 
Unless you have gobs of 
money to spend on ads
, your people represent the most efficient way to distribute your content at scale. 
 
Why? Because social algorithms primarily promote and distribute content from individuals.
 
Here's why. 👇
 
☑️ People prefer to learn and see what others they are connected with are talking about and sharing. 
 
☑️ People trust people far more than they do ads, PR, and brands in general.
 
☑️ The social networks wouldn't have a business if there’s no user growth and people aren't logging in. Think about it: If your social feed were only ads and brands when you logged in, you likely wouldn’t use the platform very much.  
 
This doesn't mean that you should abandon your brand accounts and company pages — they still matter. 
 
But what it does mean is that your company has a massive opportunity to build content distribution at scale by enabling employees to easily create, share, and engage with content.
 
Want to learn more about why and how you should activate employee influencers? I share all the details 
here
.
 
Thanks for reading, and I hope you have a wonderful weekend!
 
Best,
 
Cameron Brain 
CEO & Co-Founder
EveryoneSocial
 
P.S. - Feel free to connect with me on 
LinkedIn
 or 
Twitter
!
Make sure to follow us on social media!
 
 
 
 
EveryoneSocial, 215 W Sego Lily Dr., #708100, Sandy, Utah 84070, United States

subject: Discover the impact of generative AI on marketing
body:
Live webinar: Join us on 7/20 @ 11am EST | 4pm BST 
This message contains graphics. If you do not see the graphics, 
click here to view.
 
 
Are you taking advantage of Generative AI?
As the usage of generative AI tools is on the rise, you should explore what changes generative AI could create for your organization, your enterprise, and your industry.
Join your peers for an expert session on July 20th 
to find out what you should do to take advantage of generative AI.
In this session, you will discover: 
How could generative AI tools, such as ChatGPT, reshape your marketing?
What’s the potential impact of generative AI on your industry?

Would you like to receive emails from us about news, updates, and events?:
No
 
Message:
Hello LCW Team, 
I'd like to offer my translation and post-editing services from ENGLISH and SPANISH into FRENCH. 
I am a french native translator specialised in Technical and Marketing translation. With more than 5 years of experience and a PE certificate from RWS, I’ve been working with many translation agencies and clients. 
My usual projects include various technical documentation (heavy machinery, electronics, IT, energy, telecoms, engineering etc.) and marketing material (websites, e-commerce, softwares and applications, commercial and touristic brochures, communication material, blog articles etc.). 
You can check all my fields of expertise on my proZ profile (signature link). 
• 
• 
My rates are 0,09USD/word for translation and 0,06USD/word for post-editing or 30USD/hour. Those rates are negotiable and I’m open to a small translation test if needed. 
I currently work with SDL Trados 2022 (I also have experience with MemoQ, Memsource, SmartCAT, Globallink and XTM) and use protonmail to ensure the confidentiality of the documents you entrust me with. 
• 
• 
Please don’t hesitate to contact me if my skills suit your needs, if you wish to discuss some terms or just need further information. You will find my CV on my ProZ profile. 
I look forward to hear from you. 
Have a great day, 
____________________ 
Philippe GOUAY 
Freelance Translator 
https://www.proz.com/profile/2550380 
Tel : +33 6 13 44 63 86

Customize Your Digital Storefront Without Code
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Ever thought of selling digital products but found setting up an online store daunting? SeedProd's newest update is here to change that!
We've joined forces with Easy Digital Downloads, to help you 
build custom eCommerce sites for your digital goods
.
Now, you can effortlessly:
✅ Showcase your products

✅ Tailor your checkout process to your needs
All without needing to be a coding wizard.
But wait, there's more!
We've also enriched our library with 
12 new, fully customizable website kits
 designed to cater to various businesses.
Ready to explore these exciting features?

.
Got questions or need help with the update? Don't hesitate to hit reply. We're here to support you every step of the way.
Looking forward to seeing you conquer the digital sales world!

Hope you have a nice and low-stress last day with LCW. It's been wonderful working with you. It's been quite a journey since our initial conversations, and I'm really happy we've got the site launched and in good hands with the team.

subject: Black beauty brands are in demand, but underrepresented in stores. How can we change this?
body:
Diversifying the beauty industry ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Make room on the shelf
In the news
•
The science of hair care.
 Black consumers in the US spend $1.8 billion a year on hair products, but are three times as likely than other groups to say that they are unhappy with the available options. One consumer goods conglomerate is working to understand the chemistry behind what makes products work for curly and textured hair, as well as how consumers interact with them, by pairing a salon with an R&D lab. The project employs scientists, data analysts, and stylists to gather data and improve products. This information may help brands create more nuance for their products to gain more customer loyalty. [
NYT
]
•
To sell or not to sell.
 Many owners of small beauty businesses dream about being bought up by a larger company, but achieving that dream has become somewhat of a mixed blessing in the world of Black beauty products. Customers worry that if a brand is no longer Black-owned, the product formulas may change and not work as well, or become more expensive. But for small businesses, which often struggle to meet demand, being able to access the infrastructure of a larger company can help scale production faster and increase visibility. [
Harper’s Bazaar
]
Today, Black cosmetics brands make up only 2.5% of revenue in the beauty industry, even though Black consumers are responsible for over 11% of total beauty spending.
On McKinsey.com
•
Looking for Black beauty brands.
 The first beauty brand marketed and designed exclusively for Black women hit shelves in 1973 and was revamped in 2019. The intervening years have brought an increase in products specifically for women of color, but supply doesn’t meet demand. McKinsey senior partner 
Tiffany Burns
 and colleagues note that beauty products designed for Black consumers account for, at most, 7% of the brands available in stores. Part of the disconnect stems from entrepreneurs’ lack of access to capital and a strong business network, since Black people are still underrepresented within the beauty industry
.
•
Building up Black brands. 
As part of our ten actions for racial equality that emerged in 2020, McKinsey has dedicated research to find the best ways to help Black beauty brands by tackling barriers on both the retail and the entrepreneurial side. McKinsey’s work with the nonprofit Fifteen Percent Pledge, which urges retailers to dedicate 15% of shelf space to Black-owned brands, was focused on making sure the organization had pledges from the right mix of retailers so Black brands will show up in a variety of stores. Learn how McKinsey is helping to 
boost Black beauty brands
.
Take up (shelf) space
— Edited by Gwyn Herbein, editor, Atlanta
Was this forwarded to you? 
Sign up here
.
Or 
send us feedback
—we’d love to hear from you.
Follow our thinking
 
This email contains information about McKinsey's research, insights, services, or events. By opening our emails or clicking on links, you agree to our use of cookies and web tracking technology. For more information on how we use and protect your information, please review our 
privacy policy

body:

Jacob Pieczynski

LCW

From:
 Jake Pieczynski 
Sent:
 Thursday, July 13, 2023 7:17 PM
To:
 Ashton Vicente <a.vicente@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Website Schedule Time Work Around
 
Hey Ashton,
 
Sorry for another email. I’m writing to pass along something Alisa asked me to look into a couple days ago… She asked if there was a way we could allow people to schedule a demo of a product with Pedro right on the website… here’s my answer that I’d recommend for you should it come up again (I’ll also share this with her if she follows up in our 1:1 tomorrow).
 
Putting a sign up link on the website may lead to spam (translation bots already bombard us)
I’d instead recommend editing the email you get when you submit a contact form OR editing the redirect message that comes up after submitting the form
I would choose one of these two to edit and then add the schedule meeting link and some copy setting it up
I would not add this without first asking Pedro his opinion (he’s good at thinking of the unintended consequences of things like this and its his time you’d be putting out into the world)
 
That’s my two cents for whatever it’s worth (probably less than 2 cents…).
 
Thanks!
 
Jake
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)
Marketing & Communications Manager
LCW
