From:
 Ashton Vicente <a.vicente@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, July 5, 2023 1:00 PM
To:
 Office <office@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Action Required: LCW’s New Branding Has Launched!
Importance:
 High
 
Hi team,
 
This week marks an exciting new beginning for LCW – our new LCW branding has officially launched! If you visit our social media accounts or website, you’ll notice that these channels now feature our new look, embodying our renewed energy and commitment towards continuing this work for the next 20 years.
 
To help you navigate these changes, I’ve attached two documents that you should please prioritize reviewing as soon as possible:
 
Brand Launch Timeline Instructions
There are several changes you need to make to your own computer to ensure that you’re adopting our new visual identity.
This document includes instructions on how to make 4 required updates and three optional updates to your personal device and social channels.
We will make time to cover these changes in our upcoming All Staff meeting, but you can begin updating your device on your own (send questions to Ashton or Jake).
Please complete the 4 required updates outlined in this document by Friday, July 14
th
.
 
Brand Talking Points
This document includes valuable information on how to talk about this change with your clients and ensures we all are talking about this new brand identity in the same way.
You’ll also find information on the website and what this means for clients within this document.
No action is needed beyond your independent review of this document.
 
Additionally, the consulting team will receive information this week on how to work with the design team in prioritizing training materials for redesign (additional time will be allotted to discuss this process at our upcoming staff meeting). This process will continue through the remainder of the year with the goal that our entire library be converted to the new brand identity by 2024.
 
Thank you for your help in implementing this change – I hope you’re as excited as we are on Team MarComm!
 
Best,
Ashton
 
Ashton Vicente 
(she/her)
Communications Associate
LCW

Subject:
 Request for next week's consulting meeting - Rebrand SOP
 
Hi Dan, Sarah, and Tamara,
 
Happy Friday! I’m reaching out this morning to follow-up on the training materials rebranding SOP we took a look at together a few weeks back. Our website and social channels will officially switch over to our new brand on Monday and Alisa and Chuck will be reaching out to the team to announce this change and with some additional instructions on how to update personal devices/channels accordingly.
 
Can you please help get this rebrand SOP in front of the consulting team during next week’s weekly consulting meeting and help reenforce the importance of following this process? 
 
I’ve attached the SOP document to this message – there have been a couple minor changes, but the SOP for this process largely remains the same. Design is working on a set list of first priority items and as we sell new products they will need to be added to a tracker to be updated before delivery.
 
We will also be making time in the July All Staff meeting to talk about the individual computer updates requested and the rebranding SOP process, but we appreciate your help getting this in front of the consulting team before then so that’s not the first time they’re learning about it. Additionally, Dustin, Ashton, or I can certainly join any team meetings you think would be helpful – just let us know if this is something you’d like!
 
Thank you!
 
Ashton, Dustin, and Jake
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)
Marketing & Communications Manager
LCW

Hi Scott,
 
Thanks for looking into that issue! I’ve let everyone know to hang tight as it’s being looked at. 
 
We set aside some time to look at the website today and it’s looking great! There wasn’t anything beyond what we’re going to do ourselves after getting access to the backend for the desktop version – thank you! We really like the ribbons in the scrolling box on Our Approach too!
 
Mobile is looking really solid as well! There were just a couple things that didn’t seem to be working on the mobile version that we wanted to call to your attention (below). The first two screenshots are elements we were considering hiding on the homepage anyway.
 
The case studies button doesn’t seem to hyperlink correctly on the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
 
 
The teal square overlaps with text on the culture-first approach section of the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
The buttons don’t align in the Our Process section of the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
 
Thanks again for getting this launched successfully! We’ll check back in with you on Wednesday. Enjoy the holiday! 
 
Jake

Subject:
 Re: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
 
Hi Jake,
Good morning. Thanks for the update, and we're looking into this as well to see what options we have. It does appear to be a SSL / domain forwarding issue. Whereas when you type in 
http://www.languageandculture.com
, it forwards correctly, but if instead you use https:// it does not.
Coincidentally, I actually had another site that had a similar situation in the last week, but it was with GoDaddy as the domain registrar. When I tried to get that resolved, their tech team shared that the SSL isn't available with domain forwarding, and that's why this happens. They didn't have a fix for it. Maybe I'm just stubborn or naively optimistic, but I feel like there's got to be some workaround. 
This is on our list of things we're working on, we'll let you know as soon as we can, hoping for good news here.
Thanks,
Scott
 
On Mon, Jul 3, 2023 at 9:42 AM Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Good morning Scott and Maura,
 
I hope you had a wonderful weekend. We received a couple more messages over the weekend about the website being down. I just checked again this morning and unfortunately I still get a 
“site can’t be reached” message when you type “
languageandculture.com
” into the top of the page (please see below). It seems like this is either a redirect or DNS issue – could you please take a look so no other clients come across this?
 
We scheduled some time this morning to officially check the website out. When we get the training info from you we’ll move forward with those remaining tasks we shared in our final meeting.
 
Thank you!
 
Jake

subject: RE: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
body:
Hi Maura,
 
Yes, it looks like the redirect is working now on our end as well – thanks very much for the team’s time in fixing that issue.
 
I also wanted to let you both know that I will be transitioning out of my role here at LCW with my last day being July 14
th
. I anticipate we will have wrapped up our project by then, but please know that Ashton will be available to be your LCW contact moving forward should anything else come up. It’s been great working with you both on this website development – thank you for your partnership!
 
Looking forward to the training materials! Thank you again!
 
Jake

 Re: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
 
Hi Jake - 
 
The redirect looks like it's working fully now on our end. Please confirm on your end. Thanks!
 
As for those additional items - thanks for sharing! Post-launch QA is happening this week. We'll ask our QA tester to pay extra attention to mobile and we'll include these items in our list of fixes. We expect to have this fully completed by Monday and we'll let you know when we're done! We'll also be in touch again with site info and training materials.
 
Hope you had a nice day off! Please reach out if you have any questions.
 
Best,
Maura

On Mon, Jul 3, 2023 at 1:19 PM Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Hi Scott,
 
Thanks for looking into that issue! I’ve let everyone know to hang tight as it’s being looked at. 
 
We set aside some time to look at the website today and it’s looking great! There wasn’t anything beyond what we’re going to do ourselves after getting access to the backend for the desktop version – thank you! We really like the ribbons in the scrolling box on Our Approach too!
 
Mobile is looking really solid as well! There were just a couple things that didn’t seem to be working on the mobile version that we wanted to call to your attention (below). The first two screenshots are elements we were considering hiding on the homepage anyway.
 
The case studies button doesn’t seem to hyperlink correctly on the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
 
 
The teal square overlaps with text on the culture-first approach section of the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
The buttons don’t align in the Our Process section of the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
 
Thanks again for getting this launched successfully! We’ll check back in with you on Wednesday. Enjoy the holiday! 
 
Jake
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)
Marketing & Communications Manager
LCW

 Maura Murphy-Barrosse <
maura@buddywdd.com
>; Ashton Vicente <
a.vicente@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Re: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
 
Hi Jake,
Good morning. Thanks for the update, and we're looking into this as well to see what options we have. It does appear to be a SSL / domain forwarding issue. Whereas when you type in 
http://www.languageandculture.com
, it forwards correctly, but if instead you use https:// it does not.
Coincidentally, I actually had another site that had a similar situation in the last week, but it was with GoDaddy as the domain registrar. When I tried to get that resolved, their tech team shared that the SSL isn't available with domain forwarding, and that's why this happens. They didn't have a fix for it. Maybe I'm just stubborn or naively optimistic, but I feel like there's got to be some workaround. 
This is on our list of things we're working on, we'll let you know as soon as we can, hoping for good news here.
Thanks,
Scott
 
On Mon, Jul 3, 2023 at 9:42 AM Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Good morning Scott and Maura,
 
I hope you had a wonderful weekend. We received a couple more messages over the weekend about the website being down. I just checked again this morning and unfortunately I still get a 
“site can’t be reached” message when you type “
languageandculture.com
” into the top of the page (please see below). It seems like this is either a redirect or DNS issue – could you please take a look so no other clients come across this?
 
We scheduled some time this morning to officially check the website out. When we get the training info from you we’ll move forward with those remaining tasks we shared in our final meeting.
 
Thank you!
 
Jake

subject: The future is bright! ✨
body:
LCW adopts a new visual identity to celebrate a renewed commitment to clients for the next 20 years.
 
LCW's New Visual Identity
Dear Jacob, 
We’re excited to announce that the LCW you’ve trusted with cultural competence, diversity, equity, and inclusion for the past 20 years is getting a contemporary new look to celebrate our reenergized commitment to our clients for the next 20 years! 
 
Our new visual identity very intentionally balances our heritage with our dedication to the future of cultural competence. The bright and energizing color palette complement our signature LCW blue to capture the energy and modern innovation we bring to our clients each day, and the new interconnected ribbon motif represents a convergence of identities, experiences, and ideas on our unending journey toward changing mindsets and systems.
 
LCW remains your partner for sustained, long-term transformation and impact as we seek to build a sustainable culture of inclusion throughout each organization with which we work. Bolstered by 20 years of global experience, we’re eager to take the next step forward together into a bold, new future.
Sincerely,
Team LCW
 
 
 
 
Copyright © 2023 Language & Culture Worldwide, LLC, All rights reserved.
LCW, 4753 N Broadway, Floor 2, Chicago, Illinois 60640, USA

Subject:
 RE: Branding Launch Documents & Email Ask
 
Hi Alisa and Chuck,
 
Happy Monday! 
 
A quick update on what’s happening this week for the brand launch:
Ashton is switching over our social media branding this morning
The website developer needs to review the redirect they set up and fix an error that’s occurring when people click the website link in the old email signature (currently it’s being sent to a page not found message)
We will officially announce the new brand on social media on Wednesday
The launch blog post will go live on Wednesday
A launch email will be sent to our marketing mailing list on Wednesday
 
Can you please review the ask when you have a moment? To coincide with this timing, can you please send out this message on Wednesday at noon instead of today at noon?
 
Thank you for your help and support!
 
Jake

Subject:
 Branding Launch Documents & Email Ask
 
Hi Alisa and Chuck,
 
I’ve completed and tested the instructions and talking points we will need to disseminate to the team on Monday. Would one of you be willing to send out the attached documents and message on Monday at noon? Waiting until noon will give Ashton and I time to make sure the social channels and website have been updated.
 
Sending this from your email will help reenforce it’s importance! Please feel free to review and let me know any questions/notes.
 
Thank you!! 
 
Jake
 
-------------------
 
Send time: Monday, July 3 @12pm 
 
Subject: Action Required: LCW’s New Branding Has Launched!
 
Hi team,
 
Today marks an exciting new beginning for LCW – as of today our new LCW branding has officially launched! If you visit our social media accounts or website, you’ll notice that these channels now feature our new look, embodying our renewed energy and commitment towards continuing this work for the next 20 years.
 
To help you navigate these changes, we’re attaching two documents that we ask you prioritize reviewing as soon as possible:
 
Brand Launch Timeline Instructions
There are several changes we need you to make to your own computer to ensure that you’re adopting our new visual identity
This document includes instructions on how to make 4 required updates and three optional updates to your personal device and social channels
We will make time to cover these changes in our upcoming All Staff meeting, but you can begin updating your device on your own (send questions to Jake)
Please complete the 4 required updates outlined in this document by Friday, July 14
th
 
Brand Talking Points
This document includes valuable information on how to talk about this change with your clients and ensures we all are talking about this new brand identity in the same way
You’ll also find information on the website and what this means for clients within this document
No action is needed beyond your independent review of this document
 
Additionally, the consulting team will receive information this week on how to work with the design team in prioritizing training materials for redesign (additional time will be allotted to discuss this process at our upcoming staff meeting). This process will continue through the remainder of the year with the goal that our entire library be converted to the new brand identity by 2024.
 
Thank you for your help in implementing this change – we hope you’re as excited as we are!
 
Best,
 
Alisa & Chuck
 
Jacob Pieczynski

Subject:
 Re: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
 
Hi Jake,
Good morning. Thanks for the update, and we're looking into this as well to see what options we have. It does appear to be a SSL / domain forwarding issue. Whereas when you type in 
http://www.languageandculture.com
, it forwards correctly, but if instead you use https:// it does not.
Coincidentally, I actually had another site that had a similar situation in the last week, but it was with GoDaddy as the domain registrar. When I tried to get that resolved, their tech team shared that the SSL isn't available with domain forwarding, and that's why this happens. They didn't have a fix for it. Maybe I'm just stubborn or naively optimistic, but I feel like there's got to be some workaround. 
This is on our list of things we're working on, we'll let you know as soon as we can, hoping for good news here.
Thanks,
Scott

Jacob Top L&D tips wrap up
body:
Top L&D takeaways revealed to improve your organizations employee development journey
Hi Jacob,
 
It’s Eric, and this is the last email in this series of  Top Tips For L&D experts. Here’s a short wrap up in case you missed my previous emails.
How a head of L&D drove a 10% increase in customer satisfaction and a 5% boost in engineering throughout with personalized coaching & mentoring program
How a 6000 employees Utilities company decreased top talent attrition by 65%
How Cognyte increased their Glint engagement metrics by 7 points
How Mend increased their Women’s promotable base with a personalized development program
 
Top 3 key takeaways
Start with an outcome you can measure
. Use your HR analytics, functional KPIs or any metric the organization measures and try to drive impact on it with L&D. 
A/B test
. Split the population into a test group and control group of look-alikes and measure the difference in the metrics you are trying to measure. This is the best way to attribute success to your program.
Work in sprints
. Less open ended programs or on demand, and more focused programs, with a clear beginning and end, that are focused on one outcome.
 
May the growth be with you,
 
Eric
Head of L&D practice at Growthspace
 
P.S. 
The Josh Bersin Company recently held a webinar with Growthspace on the Future of L&D and Driving Employee Growth with New Learning Platforms.
 
You can watch and learn more.
Growthspace, 12 E 49th Street, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10017, United States

[QuickMail] the human touch
body:
when automation looks human (3 hacks)
͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌  
Today, I want to share a few hacks I often use to convey humanness (if that's even a word).
Basically, unless you are solving a bleeding neck problem, in which case you can get away with pretty much everything, the last thing you want is to look like an automated email.
That's why a lot of cold emailers include 
icebreakers
 in their outreach (a simple intro line that is unique to each prospect).
But there are other simple things you can easily experiment with that would also convey human-like communication.
For example, as humans, we often forget things when sending an email quickly to someone and feel the need to send a quick follow-up.
You know those: "I forgot X", "btw Z...", "one more thing..." and so forth.
Well, it works very nicely in a campaign and can give you an extra 5% reply rate for something that takes literally 5 minutes to implement.
For example, you can easily accomplish this in QuickMail by adding a 10 min delay between 2 email steps in a campaign or no time delay at all.
In my campaigns, I usually use 4 hours, but it depends on what I "forgot" to say and its importance/impact on the message.
If this is a link, put 2 minutes delay. For some extra information like pricing or special offer, 4 hours is fine and provides a nice nudge/valuable follow up.
Another hack is to add spelling mistake(s).
Really? in 2023?
Well, these days, this may indeed backfire. It makes you look less professional, as many people know we are using cold email software to do the outreach.
In instant messaging though, it's quite human to send one message, then another that says:
"I meant Google, not Gmail"... or something similar.
This works less so in email though, but it is worth a try for re-engaging campaigns to old existing clients, as it conveys speaking to someone you have a prior relationship with.
Finally, another one that is hugely underrated is PS.
PS in an email is a chance to mention something special and personal.
In fact, I believe this works almost better than a "fake" icebreaker and signal a genuine opinion or fact worth mentioning after the real reason you sent the email for.
"PS: for what it's worth, since you are in the cold email space, I would definitely check Jeremy's newsletter on cold outreach, I learned a few good ideas from it."
So give this a go and let me know how it goals.
... I meant "goes" of course :)
Save time & get more replies with AI + SubCampaigns
SubCampaigns have the ability to stop the current campaign a prospect runs and send another campaign instead (using their reply/email).
A simple example would be to send "I hope you had a great time off ..." to an out-of-office notification.
Well, you are in luck, we just released the ability to start a sub-campaign automatically when detecting an Out Of Office (in your Account Settings / Replies)
But there are more interesting things we can do as our AI is becoming better and better at categorizing replies.
Next week, we'll release the ability to start a sub-campaign based on any type of reply we support (interested, booking request, not the right time, not the right person...)
Oh, and while we were at it, we implemented automatic unsubscribe if we detect an 
unsubscribe request
.
I know how long it takes some of you to hunt down unsubscribe requests in all your inboxes. No More :) You can save your team hours each month by simply ticking a box!
In your account, go to Settings / Replies, and tick this box :)
If the option is not available, reply to this email and ask us to enable AI Categorization for your account. We'll do it for you at no extra cost. Just bear in mind we are still tuning it so it may be off a few times.
Deliverability Stats 
More on this next week I hope but I could not resist letting you know what one of our early users said to our support on a call.
"She said that the new analytics page is much more helpful for them because it gives them a better view of what's happening to their campaigns on a weekly basis."
🎉
Podcast: How to (Actually) Use Multi-Channel to 2x Your Reply Rate
Everyone praises combining LinkedIn outreach with cold email... but how do you actually do it and get good results from it?
In this week's episode, we share our refined process from years of leveraging LinkedIn + Email outreach and answer the most common questions people have.
The episode is 
packed 
with value.
 
Watch it here
.
Want us to cover a specific topic? Shoot your idea over at 
podcast@quickmail.io
Tool of the week: Decktopus
Want to save time creating slide decks? Consider
 
Decktopus AI
.
Say goodbye to hours spent on bad slides. With Decktopus, a single line of presentation idea transforms into a stunning presentation in less than a minute. Just choose a topic, aim, time, design, and audience. Then watch as Decktopus creates the deck you've envisioned.
Found a great tool that isn't known enough? Hit reply and let me know.
That's it for today.
Be amazing,
Jeremy
PS: Want to forward this newsletter to a friend? Do them a favor and have them register directly 
here
.

A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Watching the world economy
In the news
•
Banking on banks.
 Recent shake-ups in the US banking sector have had ripple effects across the world. That’s partly because the US economy has been irrevocably shaped by its more than 4,000 banks—more than any other country. A hundred years ago, the US had more than 30,000 banks, representing a historical lack of trust in big banks. Proponents of small banks say that their knowledge of communities enables them to offer more customized products and services, and that widespread access to loans fuels US entrepreneurship. However, smaller banks are also more susceptible to sudden economic changes. [
NPR
]
•
US inflation cools.
 The pace of inflation in the US slowed to 4.0% in May 2023, its lowest point in two years (after spiking to 9.1% in June 2022), government data reveals. Decreasing energy prices and a small uptick in food costs contributed to the decline. Some economists are keeping a close eye on housing inflation; costs related to housing went up 0.6% in May. Current conditions are “encouraging,” but the US might still experience an economic slowdown, albeit a delayed one, a chief economist said. [
FT
]
This volatility in the banking sector is likely one of the factors to have affected wider economic sentiment.
On McKinsey.com
•
Inflation still top of mind. 
Central banks across the world are looking to maintain interest rate interventions in the hopes of tempering inflation rates. In many regions and countries, inflation continues to moderate but generally remains high. Interest rates and sentiment are weighing on growth projections, and the picture is somewhat patchy, explain 
Sven Smit
, McKinsey’s chair of insights and ecosystems and chair of the McKinsey Global Institute, and colleagues. Growth in some emerging economies such as China and India are outpacing developed economies
.
•
Uneven growth. 
In advanced economies, inflation in the US has declined, partly due to falling energy prices. Energy prices also came down in the eurozone, although food prices remain high, and experts believe the UK may be able to avoid a recession in 2023. Meanwhile, India is set to contribute around 15% to global growth, making it one of the world’s fastest-growing economies. Dive deeper into 
McKinsey’s macroeconomic data and analysis of the world economy
 to understand key global trends and risks.
Consider critical economic trends
— Edited by Gwyn Herbein, editor, Atlanta

subject: Examining intersectional communities to understand race in the UK workplace
body:
Hone DEI strategy ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
AN ARTICLE A DAY, PICKED BY OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
While efforts have been
 made to advance racial equity in the workplace, fair and equitable progress has been hard to achieve. In order to move the needle on racial equity, it is crucial that we understand the varying needs of different groups, in addition to individuals with multiple “identities.” In a 
new article
 from the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility, 
Tania Holt
, 
Tunde Olanrewaju
, 
Dara Olufon
, 
Ammanuel Zegeye
, and their coauthors explore the workplace experiences of Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani women in the UK, a group who are at the greatest disadvantage on key metrics of workplace equality compared with all other ethnicity and gender combinations, according to recent McKinsey research. Dive into the data and see what UK companies can do to improve their experiences and amplify impact on racial equity.
 
Race in the UK workplace: The intersectional experience
Despite meaningful progress, achieving workplace equity has proved challenging. Addressing intersectional communities—such as Black, Bangladeshi, and Pakistani women—could yield far-reaching benefits.
Hone DEI strategy  
Quote of the day
“Economics helps you live your best life possible. It gives you the tools to systematically make decisions that will leave you, whoever you are, with whatever values you have, making the best choices you possibly can.”
—Betsey Stevenson, professor of public policy and economics at the University of Michigan, on creating a new textbook called 
Principles of Economics
 in a 
recent episode
 of the McKinsey Global Institute’s 
Forward Thinking
 podcast
Chart of the day
 
See today’s chart  
ALSO NEW
Mexican consumers seek value and convenience—and find it online
Our latest consumer sentiment survey in Mexico reveals lasting pandemic effects on consumer behavior, including reduced spending and more online shopping.
Dive into the data 
 
An interview on building organizational resilience: A board-level priority in today’s challenging times
Boards of directors play an important role in helping companies navigate economic uncertainty. Collaboration among CEOs, boards, and owners helps effectively manage today’s complex business environment.
Make resilience a board priority  
Logistics Disruptors: Data-driven insights for greener shipping
With AI’s help, ships are using less fuel and keeping people safe at sea, says ZeroNorth’s Pelle Sommansson.
Transform an industry 
 
— Edited by Joyce Yoo
,
 editor, New York

subject: RE: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
body:
Hi Scott,
 
Thanks for looking into that issue! I’ve let everyone know to hang tight as it’s being looked at. 
 
We set aside some time to look at the website today and it’s looking great! There wasn’t anything beyond what we’re going to do ourselves after getting access to the backend for the desktop version – thank you! We really like the ribbons in the scrolling box on Our Approach too!
 
Mobile is looking really solid as well! There were just a couple things that didn’t seem to be working on the mobile version that we wanted to call to your attention (below). The first two screenshots are elements we were considering hiding on the homepage anyway.
 
The case studies button doesn’t seem to hyperlink correctly on the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
 
 
The teal square overlaps with text on the culture-first approach section of the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
The buttons don’t align in the Our Process section of the homepage (iPhone 14 max, safari)
 
Thanks again for getting this launched successfully! We’ll check back in with you on Wednesday. Enjoy the holiday! 
 
Jake
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)
Marketing & Communications Manager
LCW

From:
 Scott Daigger <scott@buddywdd.com> 
Sent:
 Monday, July 3, 2023 9:41 AM
To:
 Jake Pieczynski <j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Maura Murphy-Barrosse <maura@buddywdd.com>; Ashton Vicente <a.vicente@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
 
Hi Jake,
Good morning. Thanks for the update, and we're looking into this as well to see what options we have. It does appear to be a SSL / domain forwarding issue. Whereas when you type in 
http://www.languageandculture.com
, it forwards correctly, but if instead you use https:// it does not.
Coincidentally, I actually had another site that had a similar situation in the last week, but it was with GoDaddy as the domain registrar. When I tried to get that resolved, their tech team shared that the SSL isn't available with domain forwarding, and that's why this happens. They didn't have a fix for it. Maybe I'm just stubborn or naively optimistic, but I feel like there's got to be some workaround. 
This is on our list of things we're working on, we'll let you know as soon as we can, hoping for good news here.
Thanks,
Scott
 
On Mon, Jul 3, 2023 at 9:42 AM Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Good morning Scott and Maura,
 
I hope you had a wonderful weekend. We received a couple more messages over the weekend about the website being down. I just checked again this morning and unfortunately I still get a 
“site can’t be reached” message when you type “
languageandculture.com
” into the top of the page (please see below). It seems like this is either a redirect or DNS issue – could you please take a look so no other clients come across this?
 
We scheduled some time this morning to officially check the website out. When we get the training info from you we’ll move forward with those remaining tasks we shared in our final meeting.
 
Thank you!
 
Jake
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)
Marketing & Communications Manager

Hi Scott,
 
What a wonderful way to end the week indeed! Thanks very much for letting us know! We know you said it would take some time to switch over fully so we’ll check back in on it on Monday. 
 
We did have a few people message us saying that 
languageandculture.com

langaugeandculture.com

Thanks again for getting this launched! Very excited!

Hi 
NAME
,
 
I hope you’re having a great week! I’m writing today to invite you to our upcoming webinar, “Creating a culture of inclusion that fosters high performance.”
 
Join LCW Principal Consultant Sarah Nodarse and Associate Consultant Vince Bongiovanni on 
Wednesday, July 12 at 12pm
 for a closer look at how LCW’s Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Model can foster belonging in the workplace and produce equitable outcomes for employees. 
 
In this session, we will:
Share 
the genesis & structure of 
the SCI Model 
Discuss 
how we use the SCI model to 
diagnose organizations’ current state
Provide two case studies that demonstrate the model’s impact 
 
Visit our website to learn more and reserve your seat:

Hope to see you there!

subject: Re: Invoice update
body:
Hey Jake,
Wow! Congrats on the new gig. They're lucky to have you as much as LCW will miss your talent. You're a super partner to work with and hope we can on something else at some point.
Glad to see the site go live! I think it really looks great. I may be biased but I think it has such a nice, fresh feel and very friendly. Hope it makes a big difference in everyone's perspective of the brand.
Appreciate you keeping me in the loop and connecting me to Ashton in case something comes up. Certainly glad to have your personal email so we can keep in touch!
Have an amazing holiday! Keep your fingers.
Take care,
Brendan
On Fri, Jun 30, 2023 at 11:32 AM Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
Hey Brendan,
 
I hope you had a great week and are preparing for a fun holiday weekend.
 
I really appreciated your notes and ideas on the website design. The website is launching today/through this weekend so if you go to 
lcwinclusion.com
 or 
languageandculture.com
 you’ll see it switched over by Monday. With the quick turnaround, we haven’t had a chance to implement some additional feedback given by some folks – yours included. I really like your note about the different color overlays by section and wonder if that’s a possible addition for future improvement. You’ll notice the scary icon is still on the site too… we need to find a replacement for that after the launch as well.
 
I also wanted to update you that I’ll be transitioning out of my role here at LCW on July 14
th
. It’s been a great opportunity and I’m proud to have collaborated with talented folks like yourself to redefine the brand and launch a new website, but I’m going to head back into the nonprofit world, specifically in the education space, where my heart truly lies as Director of Marketing and Communications for an org here in Chicago (who also is experiencing an identity crisis after 20 years of work and a new direction). I know I have your email and phone number, but in case you need to reach me my personal email is 
jacob.pieczynski@outlook.com
. 
 
We’re still working out some final transition details, but I think my colleague Ashton Vicente (
a.vicente@lcwmail.com
) will likely be the contact I provide you in case you need anything LCW related moving forward. As this gets finalized, I’ll ask her to reach out to you so you have her contact information.
 
Again, thanks so much for your help! It’s so exciting for this to launch this weekend. Hope it’s a good weekend for you there!
 
Best,
 
Jake

Sent:
 Wednesday, June 21, 2023 5:27 PM
To:
 Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Re: Invoice update
 
Hey Jake!
 
Hope all has been well. Thanks so much for reaching out and sharing this! Thrilled to see it come to life :)
 
I certainly love the energy and the feeling of the graphics package and how the logo, typography and colors expand the brand. Love it. It feels so much more vibrant, current and friendly. I'm going to have to steal a couple screen grabs of the current site before this goes live.
 
I don't have too much input to make. I really like the typestyling from eyebrow in all caps, the consistent dark blue and weight of the headlines and the body copy works just as I had hoped for when there are some heavy paragraphs of detail.
 
One of my favorite things is when one independent arrow points to a negative space and then solid square. I would try to use that more often over the occasions where it is just negative space and solid square. When possible, I do like when the square shifts to an alternate color from whatever that main section is. (Hope that makes sense)
 
Also like how the logo can be repeated as a pattern in its single-color version. One thing that does throw me a little is the logo slightly rotated when it appears behind a single clipped person. Maybe it's fine as it give some extra life, but there is so much precision to the geometry, I feel some tension.
 
I wonder if the stock photos could be treated somehow to feel more "owned" by the brand. There are so many, it is hard to have a super-consistent style, but I would create some screens. More candid and less-staged would be an important one. One trick that does work, and you can notice it in a few places already, is throwing a slight tone over the top of the image with translucency. See Our Impact page – the one on the bottom with the inset quote is likely my favorite on the whole site. Because the photos are frequent, I'd resist using the logo as a watermark again but maybe some other graphic could be applied. Or another trick would be to use the titles they represent (i.e. TRANSLATION, CONSULTING, CULTURE-FIRST) be the thing that is the watermark. That may be a whole new design language, but you probably get what I mean.
 
Here's one weird comment... the very first icon I saw was the Cross-Cultural icon:
This might be just me, but I see a confused or angry face like I just lost at Angry Birds. And now, you can't un-see that! ;)
 
Thanks for all!
 
Let me know if any of my thoughts are confusing. Happy to chat any time!
 
Take care,
 
Brendan

I wanted to give you a heads up and let you view the development website. I’ll drop the log in information below – if you’d like to take a look, feel free and let me know if you have any feedback! Hey Jake!
 
That's great to hear. Glad you got away. Gotta love Mexico and esp with a nice all-inclusive. Not having to plan meals and having drinks at the ready is the way to go :)
 
Bad/sad news with Elgin Academy. As Rich predicted, some politics got in the way and FAR into development, they threw our work to a school alum that fancies herself as a branding/marketing expert. The board lead that hired us asked if we wanted to continue as support for her and we said... um, no thanks. Rich thinks they hurt themselves to the point of threatening the school's existence as they haven't created any marketing yet and it was needed in February to recruit new students. It's a real shame. Plus, I loved what we did. Oh well. Maybe they'll come back to us before it closes!
 
I'll let you know when I get something in the mail from the invoice! Thanks for pushing it through :)
 
Take care,
 
Brendan
 
 
 
On Tue, Apr 11, 2023 at 9:10 AM Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com

Hi Brendan,
 
Sorry for the delay! I’m glad to hear you were able to able to get away for a while with your family! I had no idea you had 6 kids – that must have been a packed house, but sounds like a great change for some quality family time in a really cool location. Sounds wonderful – I have to check out Cave Creek some day!
 
My girlfriend and I took a real vacation (we took off and weren’t working remote like we normally do) and went to an all-inclusive in Mexico. It was a really nice and needed time with lots of sun and good food. I’m very grateful it worked out and we were able to get the time away!
 
I submitted your invoice and will keep checking on it. If you don’t mind, can you please send me a message when you see it go through? That way I don’t keep bothering them about it. It might take a bit to process (we have a third-party accountant service) – so apologies in advance for any delay but I’ll keep on it.
 
Hey I’ve been meaning to ask you – I haven’t talked to my uncle in a bit, did you end up getting to finish the work for that school? Hope all is going smoothly with the rest of your clients!
 
Thanks again and let me know if you need anything from me.
 
Best,
 
Jake

subject: [Upcoming Webinar] 7 Key Trends That Will Impact Your Strategic Planning
body:
Join us on 07/12 for a complimentary expert session 
This message contains graphics. If you do not see the graphics, 
click here to view.
 
 
Hi Jacob,
If you cannot adequately spot trends, you’re prone to jeopardizing your strategic plans.
This can further affect your organization’s digital transformation and limit your ability to capitalize on new market opportunities that disruptions may offer.
Join your peers for an expert session on 07/12
 to enable yourself to better spot trends, minimize complexity, embrace uncertainty, and drive confidence in 
decision-making while exploring bold new opportunities.
Discussion Topics: 
Identifying critical areas of disruption in 7 key areas

subject: You're invited to our Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Webinar!
body:
MY APOLOGIES – this looks great, I just simplified the bullet points a bit (see red), thank you!
 
 
Hi 
NAME
,
 
I hope you’re having a great week! I’m writing today to invite you to our upcoming webinar, “Creating a culture of inclusion that fosters high performance.”
 
Join LCW Principal Consultant Sarah Nodarse and Associate Consultant Vince Bongiovanni on 
Wednesday, July 12 at 12pm
 for a closer look at how LCW’s Sustainable Culture of Inclusion Model can foster belonging in the workplace and produce equitable outcomes for employees. 
 
In this session, we will:
Share 
the genesis & structure of 
the SCI Model 
Discuss 
how we use the SCI model to 
diagnose organizations’ current state
Provide two case studies that demonstrate the model’s impact 
 
Visit our website to learn more and reserve your seat: 
https://languageandculture.com/creating-a-culture-of-inclusion-webinar/
 
Hope to see you there!
 
 
 
 
-

subject: Re: Website Redirect Down - RE: Website is live!
body:
Hi Jake,
Good morning. Thanks for the update, and we're looking into this as well to see what options we have. It does appear to be a SSL / domain forwarding issue. Whereas when you type in 
http://www.languageandculture.com
, it forwards correctly, but if instead you use https:// it does not.
Coincidentally, I actually had another site that had a similar situation in the last week, but it was with GoDaddy as the domain registrar. When I tried to get that resolved, their tech team shared that the SSL isn't available with domain forwarding, and that's why this happens. They didn't have a fix for it. Maybe I'm just stubborn or naively optimistic, but I feel like there's got to be some workaround. 
This is on our list of things we're working on, we'll let you know as soon as we can, hoping for good news here.
Thanks,
Scott

subject: RE: Branding Launch Documents & Email Ask
body:
Hi Alisa and Chuck,
 
Happy Monday! 
 
A quick update on what’s happening this week for the brand launch:
Ashton is switching over our social media branding this morning
The website developer needs to review the redirect they set up and fix an error that’s occurring when people click the website link in the old email signature (currently it’s being sent to a page not found message)
We will officially announce the new brand on social media on Wednesday
The launch blog post will go live on Wednesday
A launch email will be sent to our marketing mailing list on Wednesday
 
Can you please review the ask when you have a moment? To coincide with this timing, can you please send out this message on Wednesday at noon instead of today at noon?
 
Thank you for your help and support!
 
Jake

From:
 Jake Pieczynski

 Thursday, June 29, 2023 4:51 PM
To:
 Alisa Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>; Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Ashton Vicente <a.vicente@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Branding Launch Documents & Email Ask
 
Hi Alisa and Chuck,
 
I’ve completed and tested the instructions and talking points we will need to disseminate to the team on Monday. Would one of you be willing to send out the attached documents and message on Monday at noon? Waiting until noon will give Ashton and I time to make sure the social channels and website have been updated.
 
Sending this from your email will help reenforce it’s importance! Please feel free to review and let me know any questions/notes.
 
Thank you!! 
 
Jake
 
-------------------
 
Send time: Monday, July 3 @12pm 
 
Subject: Action Required: LCW’s New Branding Has Launched!
 
Hi team,
 
Today marks an exciting new beginning for LCW – as of today our new LCW branding has officially launched! If you visit our social media accounts or website, you’ll notice that these channels now feature our new look, embodying our renewed energy and commitment towards continuing this work for the next 20 years.
 
To help you navigate these changes, we’re attaching two documents that we ask you prioritize reviewing as soon as possible:
 
Brand Launch Timeline Instructions
There are several changes we need you to make to your own computer to ensure that you’re adopting our new visual identity
This document includes instructions on how to make 4 required updates and three optional updates to your personal device and social channels
We will make time to cover these changes in our upcoming All Staff meeting, but you can begin updating your device on your own (send questions to Jake)
Please complete the 4 required updates outlined in this document by Friday, July 14
th
 
Brand Talking Points
This document includes valuable information on how to talk about this change with your clients and ensures we all are talking about this new brand identity in the same way
You’ll also find information on the website and what this means for clients within this document
No action is needed beyond your independent review of this document
 
Additionally, the consulting team will receive information this week on how to work with the design team in prioritizing training materials for redesign (additional time will be allotted to discuss this process at our upcoming staff meeting). This process will continue through the remainder of the year with the goal that our entire library be converted to the new brand identity by 2024.
 
Thank you for your help in implementing this change – we hope you’re as excited as we are!
 
Best,
 
Alisa & Chuck
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)

I thought you might find this interesting. Virbela is a virtual reality meeting platform that we use with the organization, IT knowledge and abilities network. Apparently PwC has tried it out for DEI training. 
 
Get 
Outlook for iOS
From:
 Pat Maher <
Pat.Maher@spr.com
>
Sent:
 Wednesday, June 21, 2023 11:00:20 AM
To:
 ITKAN Council <
ITKANCouncil@spr.com
>
Subject:
 PwC Virbela Cannes experience
 
 
Everyone, 
 
I have attended the above-noted virtual experience/meeting for the past few days. It’s been a great experience and very informative regarding 
PwC (Price Waterhouse Cooper)
 immersion and research associated with metaverse experiences and engagement. The trainings are conducted on a yacht, which is fun. Their research indicates that training on soft skills like empathy development and other DEI training is highly effective in virtual worlds…much more than either online or other remote learning. Students exhibited greater empathy, retention and ability to implement new skills by training in a virtual environment. The difference between other remote learning and virtual was significant. This might have applicability to other industries/fields like training physicians and other health professionals in being more empathetic listeners to PwD and other diverse populations. I see applicability to many industries.
 
Anyway, I have met folks from throughout the world. It’s been a great experience and I’m grateful for the opportunity. I have found the metaverse experience a great way to learn, engage with others globally, and incorporate play into the day…which all research suggests is very healthy!
 
I’d encourage you to find time to explore OC and attend one of the great 
community events
 
Sincerely,
 
Pat 
 
Pat Maher | Director, Civic Engagement
(he/him/his)
SPR | 233 S. Wacker Dr. Suite 3500 | Chicago, IL 60606
M. 630.220.8895
www.spr.com

In our latest podcast episode, Maya Hu-Chan shared a story about how microaggressions eventually made her change her own name. “Microaggressions,” she explained, “are subtle put-downs or insults, whether intentional or unintentional, that are regularly experienced by marginalized groups”—such as not learning how to pronounce someone’s name. Asking how to pronounce someone’s name and practicing with them is an inclusive behavior that communicates genuine care and respect. “I can't tell you how much that I appreciate that,” she said. ⏯️ Check out the full podcast and transcript on our website: https://hubs.li/Q01Wh_4p0 #DEI #Podcast #Culture #AANHPI

From:
 Jake Pieczynski <j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, June 30, 2023 10:17 AM
To:
 Briza Cardenas <b.cardenas@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 All Staff Asks/Meeting time
 
Briza! 
 
I hope you’re having a wonderful time away and don’t see this until Monday!
 
A couple quick things for your return:
 
Can we please add two things to the All Staff agenda for July 12?
Following up on personal computer/channel updates for the rebrand
                                                    
i.
     
I wrote an email for Alisa/Chuck to send on Monday that announces the brand launch and gives out instructions on updating computers, email signatures, social channels, etc.
                                                   
ii.
     
Folks will have these materials and can start updating on their own immediately next week
                                                  
iii.
     
This time would be to review any processes that are giving folks trouble/or demonstrate how to execute some of the more complicated processes live
                                                  
iv.
     
15 minutes?
Training material rebrand SOP 
                                                    
i.
     
Consultants will be presented with a CLT approved rebrand process that will have them coordinate with design to update needed materials with rebranded identity standards
                                                   
ii.
     
This time would be Dustin and I summarizing the process and taking questions that the team has
                                                  
iii.
     
10 minutes?
Alisa asked me to meet with you to talk about my transition – I’m honestly not really sure why but she made it seem like you were doing this with other folks too… I’ll schedule time and you’ll see that request come through, but please know I’m going to be very blunt with anyone that tries to say you can take over anything on our list and tell them that you are capable of doing it but it’s not your job/you can’t be expected to just pick up everything… so please don’t think I’m scheduling this time to tell you I’m recommending you take over our tasks 
 
Enjoy the rest of your time off!!
 
Jake
 
Jacob Pieczynski

subject: What potential paths could the global economy take from now to 2030?
body:
New research from McKinsey Global Institute  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
 
 
TODAY’S NEWS. TOMORROW’S INSIGHTS.
A daily newsletter from McKinsey & Company
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
The future of wealth and growth
In the news
•
Still fighting inflation.
 As central banks attempt to lower inflation to 2%, policy makers concede that they’ll likely need more time to fight it—which means continuing to raise interest rates for now. In Europe and America, government leaders say that prices are still too high and more progress needs to be made. For some countries, inflation initially cooled when economies reopened following the COVID-19-related global lockdowns. Since then, inflation has risen once more, spurred on by different sources such as strong consumer demand. [
Reuters
]
•
A fragile recovery.
 The world economy is expected to make a tenuous recovery in 2023 and 2024 as inflation and elevated interest rates continue to affect banking, consumer spending, and growth, according to the OECD. Although the economy is improving, risks abound, including the ongoing war in Ukraine and rising debt in developing nations. Global GDP is now projected to grow 2.7% in 2023, a 0.5% increase from the OECD’s previous forecast. Economies in Asia—including China, India, and Singapore—will fuel much of that growth. [
AP
]
Productivity growth among G-7 countries has been sluggish, falling from 1.8% per year between 1980 and 2000 to 0.8% from 2000 to 2018.
On McKinsey.com
•
It’s one thing on paper. 
Asset price inflation over the past two decades created about $160 trillion in wealth—on paper. At the same time, economic growth was sluggish, inequality rose, and every $1.00 in investment ended up generating $1.90 in debt. With recent turbulence in the banking sector and heightened geopolitical tensions, conditions have changed from the years of loose money and seemingly endless increases in wealth, according to 
Sven Smit
, McKinsey’s chair of insights and ecosystems and of the McKinsey Global Institute, and colleagues.
•
Scenario planning, with a twist. 
As leaders prepare for a potentially protracted period of economic uncertainty, McKinsey has modeled four possible scenarios to understand what the future might hold for the world’s balance sheet. Three of them are far from ideal. However, in one scenario, investment strengthens and is productive, accelerating productivity growth. That could reshape the economic, banking, and investment landscape. Consider what actions decision makers can take to 
prepare for an unusually broad range of economic outcomes
.
See the full report
— Edited by Katherine Tam, editor, New York

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 July 2, 2023
body:
Summer issue of Training Industry Magazine, new podcast episode and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
“When change hits, our job begins,” said Sandy Ogg, founder at CEO.works and closing keynote at the Training Industry Conference & Expo (TICE). This past week, more than 600 learning leaders gathered to connect and share ideas on how to prepare their people and organizations to move at the pace of change. From inspiring keynotes and breakout sessions to roundtable discussions and networking opportunities, the energy and passion of our training community left me feeling optimistic for the future of learning and development (L&D).
During TICE, we also recognized the authors behind our 20 most-read articles of the year at the 
Training Industry Readership and Editors' Awards
 luncheon. Congratulations to all the winners and thank you to everyone who contributes content to Training Industry.
I hope that you find the resources in this newsletter helpful as you kick off the third quarter and continue executing your learning strategy. As always, we love hearing from you. Please email us at 
editor@trainingindustry.com
.
Michelle Eggleston Schwartz, CPTM
Editor in Chief 
Hot off the Press: Training Industry Magazine’s Summer Issue
The Summer 2023 issue of Training Industry Magazine is out now! It's up to L&D to prepare organizations for the increasing pace of change; but first, we need to align our goals and how to measure them. This edition includes articles on developing a performance-first mindset, giving better feedback, bridging the digital skills gap, designing employee competency rubrics and more. Check it out now!
Read Now
 
The Business of Learning, Episode 65: The Employee Experience — What’s L&D Got to Do With It?
For many training professionals, creating a culture of learning sits on the long list of “nice-to-haves.” So, in our latest podcast episode, we turned to the pros for tips on integrating learning into the employee experience: We spoke with Sydney Savion, senior director of learning services at Google and member of Training Industry Magazine’s editorial board, Thomas Fenstermacher, CPTM, learning specialist at TrellisRX, and Eric McArdle, CPTM, manager of training and knowledge management at Cisco. 
Listen Now

We provide data-driven analysis and best practices for L&D by capturing the perspectives of learning professionals, learners and training companies across a wide array of industries. subject: Top 10 reports this quarter
body:
At #1: The economic potential of generative AI ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
 
For direct answers to complex questions, check out 
McKinsey Explainers
.
Top Ten Reports │ Second Quarter 2023
Our top ten reports this quarter look at the state of organizations, how to accelerate productivity growth, and more. At No. 1, 
Michael Chui
, 
Eric Hazan
, 
Roger Roberts
, 
Alex Singla
, 
Kate Smaje
, 
Alex Sukharevsky
, 
Lareina Yee
, and 
Rodney Zemmel
 reveal how gen AI could unlock trillions of dollars in value across sectors.
1. The economic potential of generative AI: The next productivity frontier
Generative AI is poised to unleash the next wave of productivity. We take a first look at where business value could accrue and the potential impacts on the workforce.
 
Preview the frontier
 
 
2. The State of Organizations 2023: Ten shifts transforming organizations
Organizations today face ten significant shifts. Here’s what to do about them.
 
Make change at scale
 
3. The future of wealth and growth hangs in the balance
The past two decades have generated $160 trillion in paper wealth but sluggish growth and rising inequality. What comes next?
 
4 scenarios
 
 
4. 
Reimagining economic growth in Africa: Turning diversity into opportunity
Africa’s economy downshifted over the last decade, yet half of its people live in countries that have thrived on the continent. Africa has the human capital and natural resources to accelerate productivity and reimagine its economic growth, which is, more than ever, vital for the welfare of the world.
 
Download the full report
 
 
 
 
5. 
State of grocery Europe 2023: Living with and responding to uncertainty
2022 was overshadowed by inflation. As that shadow is lifting, European grocers are gearing up for future growth by investing in private labels, retail media, automation, and sustainability.
 
8 trends for 2023
 
 
 
 
6. 
The business of sports and the quest for inclusion for women
For all the progress toward equality on the field, sports administration remains dominated by men. A fairer, more inclusive industry would benefit everyone.
 
Change the game
 
 
 
 
7. 
Delivering impact from US green bank financing
Green bank financing could mobilize hundreds of billions in investment toward net-zero emissions by 2050 as well as advancing environmental justice in the US.
 
Learn how
 
 
 
 
8. 
Uniquely Austin: Stewarding growth in America’s boomtown
Austin is a booming region and an ascending economic powerhouse, but there are growing pains. Together, the region’s leaders can build a sustainable and inclusive future.
 
Read more
 
 
 
 
9. 
Fulfilling the potential of US higher education
With bold, decisive action, the US higher education sector could expand its impact, deliver on its promise of more-equitable outcomes, and improve the nation’s economic competitiveness.
 
5 decisive actions
 
 
 
 
10. 
Aluminum decarbonization at a cost that makes sense
Production of this important metal has a significant carbon footprint. The path toward greener aluminum will require the participation of multiple stakeholders.
 
Start the journey
 
 
 
 
Follow our thinking
 
Share these insights
Did you enjoy this newsletter?
 
Forward it to colleagues and friends
 so they can subscribe too. Was this issue forwarded to you? Sign up for it and sample our 40+ other free email subscriptions
 
here

subject: email deliverability tools that actually help
body:
Hi Jacob,
One problem a lot of Marketing and Communications Managers face, paradoxically, is succeeding too much. You work hard to keep up with improvements in email marketing tech and eventually the improvements are too small to justify the effort. 
But, of course, you want to keep getting better! And we want to help. 
That’s why our CEO, Larry Kim,  is hosting a 
live free webinar
 on July 12 (1PM ET, 10AM PT).
He’ll be breaking down his approach to email deliverability which has helped our clients 5x email performance. Plus, he’ll be joined by Marc Gawith from Pictory.ai to talk about using AI to produce super-effective shortform video content. 
Register today
 and we’ll see you there! 
Sincerely,
Kelsie Gallagher
Customers.ai
 (Formerly MobileMonkey)
If you don't want to hear from me again, please 
let me know
.

subject: Training Industry Announces the 2023 Training Industry Editorial Award Winners and Other L&D News ...
body:
Business News This Week
View this email in your browser
July 1, 2023
Industry News from 
Training Industry
Sign up to receive this newsletter each week
 
Announcing the 2023 Training Industry Editorial Award Winners
RALEIGH, N.C. — June 28, 2023
Training Industry, Inc. today announced its 2023 Readership and Editors’ Award winners during a luncheon at the Training Industry Conference and Expo in Raleigh, North Carolina.
Read More
Announcing the 2023 Training Industry Top Training Companies Lists: Online Learning Libraries
RALEIGH, N.C. — June 29, 2023
Training Industry today announced its selections for the 2023 Top Training Companies™ lists for the Online Learning Libraries sector of the corporate learning and development (L&D) market. Training Industry, the leading research and information resource for corporate learning leaders, prepares the Training Industry Top 20 report on critical sectors of the corporate training marketplace to better inform professionals about the best and most innovative providers of training services and technologies.
Read More
CONTENT DEVELOPMENT
Introducing The Story Generator: simpleshow’s Secure AI Script Automation
BERLIN — June 27, 2023
  
The explainer video platform simpleshow is known for the simple creation of explainer videos with highly automated text-to-video technology.
Read More →
CONTENT DEVELOPMENT
WeLearn and Meahana Form Strategic Learning and Development Partnership
CHICAGO — June 27, 2023
  
WeLearn, a learning solutions and custom content creation company, and Meahana, a facilitator-first learning platform, are excited to announce they have formed a strategic learning and development partnership.
Read More →
CONTENT DEVELOPMENT
Creating Vibrant Business Videos in Seconds Starts now: Breakthrough AI-Powered Script and Video Creator now Available From Vyond
SAN MATEO, Ca. — June 28, 2023
  
Vyond Go, the industry’s first AI-powered script and video creator, is now available from Vyond.
Read More →
LEARNING TECHNOLOGIES
Cognizant and ServiceNow Announce Strategic Partnership to Accelerate Adoption of AI-Driven Automation
TEANECK, NJ and SANTA CLARA, Calif. — June 28, 2023
  
Cognizant (NASDAQ: CTSH) and ServiceNow (NYSE: NOW) today announced a strategic partnership to advance adoption of AI‑driven automation across industries.
Read More →
LEADERSHIP
Cappfinity Unveils Three new Leadership Talent Solutions to Help Organizations Navigate the Fourth Industrial Revolution
NEW YORK — June 26, 2023
  
Cappfinity, a leading talent acquisition and management solutions provider, today unveiled three additions to its comprehensive suite of science-backed, leadership solutions.
Read More →
LEARNING TECHNOLOGIES
Think Learning Delivers CSTF Interface to Over 20 NHS Trusts 
BRISTOL, U.K. — June 27, 2023
  
Think Learning, Totara Global Partner of the Year for 2023, is now over halfway in its mission to enable 50 NHS Trusts to automate the exchange of mandatory training data between their Totara LMS platforms and ESR (the NHS Oracle HR system).
Read More →

HBR Bestsellers

How to Think More Strategically (HBR Special Issue)
 
See the big picture. Strategic thinking is a critical part of getting and staying ahead. Learn how to spot trends, ask smarter questions, and anticipate the future.
 
 
 
 
 
HBR Guide to Building Your Business Case Ebook + Tools
 
Whether you are pitching a new product, proposing a process improvement, or seeking funds, a persuasive business case is essential. This tool will help you build a business case that clearly shows the value of your idea.
 
 
 
 
 
Playing to Win Strategy Toolkit
 
With expert advice from Roger Martin, detailed case studies, customizable meeting decks, video clips, and the best-selling ebook 
Playing to Win
—everything you need for a winning strategy is right here. It’s perfect for team leaders, consultants, and non-profits to develop and implement successful strategy.
 
 
 
 
 
Artificial Intelligence Library
 
The artificial intelligence (AI) revolution is well underway. How will AI impact your industry, company, and career? Get up to speed on the latest research with this specially priced set. Whether you are an entrepreneur, manager, or leader, learn what it takes to successfully compete in the AI world.
 
 
 
 
 
The First 90 Days: Proven Strategies for Getting Up to Speed Faster and Smarter
 
The world's most trusted guide for leaders in transition. By walking you through every aspect of the transition scenario, author Michael Watkins identifies the most common pitfalls new leaders encounter and provides the tools and strategies you need to avoid them.

subject: How boards can build organizational resilience, revenue growth techniques for restaurants, what Gen Z wants, and more: The Daily Read weekender
body:
Essential reads for the weekend ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Share this email
 
 
Share this email on 
LinkedIn
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Twitter
  
 
 
Share this email on 
Facebook
  
 
 
 
 
CURATED PICKS FOR YOUR DOWNTIME, FROM OUR EDITORS
 
Brought to you by 
Liz Hilton Segel
, chief client officer and managing partner, global industry practices, & 
Homayoun Hatami
, managing partner, global client capabilities
Summer is in full swing
 in the Northern hemisphere—and Independence Day and Canada Day are just around the corner. As you get ready to celebrate, take a moment to check out the week’s big reads on building organizational resilience, revenue growth management for restaurants, Gen Z, and more.
 
McKinsey senior partner Frithjof Lund and the CEO of Norges Bank Investment Management, Nicolai Tangen, talk about how boards can identify opportunities for resilient growth amid economic uncertainty.
Make resilience a board priority
 
McKinsey’s Jen Henry, Katharine Mattox, Duncan Miller, and their coauthors explain why revenue growth management (RGM) is a key ingredient for restaurants.
Start your journey
 
What does Gen Z—13- to 27-year-olds—want in the workplace and as consumers? Find out on the latest 
Five Fifty
 from 
McKinsey Quarterly
.
Understand the needs of Gen Z
 
Our weekly briefing note on sustainable and inclusive growth explores sustainable agriculture, converting refineries to renewable fuels, and more.
Get updated
TECH FOR EXECS
 
Demystifying the data mesh: how it can help your organization
Welcome to Tech for Execs: quick primers on key technology concepts to get leaders up to speed.
What is a data mesh?
 For both new and experienced data practitioners, managing data is not a trivial matter. Data mesh is a relatively new approach to data management. By decentralizing data to specific business domains like sales, marketing, or customer service, teams can have more ownership over their data and easily share it across the organization.
How does it work?
 A data mesh is as much 
a cultural shift as it is a technological one
. Part of this is thinking of 
data as a product
, rather than a by-product of a process—and treating data producers as product owners, who can manage their own data and create policies with their best interests in mind.
What are the biggest benefits of a data mesh?
 Organizations increasingly rely on efficient data collection, storage, and access so cross-functional teams can use it effectively, across the business. A decentralized data architecture is therefore great for scalability and accessibility, especially when used alongside 
cloud technologies
. It reduces operational bottlenecks that come with centralized systems, freeing up technical teams so they can focus on more complex systems.
Where do I start?
 Moving to a data mesh means 
overhauling technology, processes, and the way people work
. So you need to start with a solid strategy. This might involve investing in 
DataOps
 to accelerate design and development, as well as fostering a data culture across the organization.
QUOTE OF THE DAY
“The best companies try to look at technologies that are relevant and integrate them into end outcomes, such as productivity, experience, or, in some cases, efficiency.”
—Biswa Misra, group chief technology officer and life operations officer at AIA Group, on the insurance industry adopting new technologies in “
Modernizing the mindset: An interview with Biswa Misra
”
chart of the day
 
See today’s chart 
Ready to unwind?
What is e-commerce?
E-commerce is the buying and selling of goods online. By optimizing e-commerce as part of a broader digital commerce transformation, sellers stand to attract more customers and earn more profits.
Deliver value
 
Data Points: Your weekly quiz
How well do you know the numbers behind the changes in business, society, and the world? Take the McKinsey weekly quiz to find out.
Take the quiz
 
42-Down: Industry that may be affected by generative AI
Know the answer? Test yourself with the latest McKinsey Crossword, Generative AI | No. 134
Embrace the future
 
—Edited by Joyce Yoo, editor, New York
Follow our thinking
 
Share these insights

.

subject: RE: Website is live!
body:
Hi Scott,
 
What a wonderful way to end the week indeed! Thanks very much for letting us know! We know you said it would take some time to switch over fully so we’ll check back in on it on Monday. 
 
We did have a few people message us saying that languageandculture.com is down. It’s strange, when I click the hyperlink in your email it works, but when I type in langaugeandculture.com into my browser, it sends me to a “site can’t be reached” page. Could you please ask the QA folks to look into the dns records and see what might be causing this?
 
Thanks again for getting this launched! Very excited!
 
Best,
 
Jake
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)
Marketing & Communications Manager
LCW

subject: RE: Invoice update
body:
Hey Brendan,
 
I hope you had a great week and are preparing for a fun holiday weekend.
 
I really appreciated your notes and ideas on the website design. The website is launching today/through this weekend so if you go to lcwinclusion.com or languageandculture.com you’ll see it switched over by Monday. With the quick turnaround, we haven’t had a chance to implement some additional feedback given by some folks – yours included. I really like your note about the different color overlays by section and wonder if that’s a possible addition for future improvement. You’ll notice the scary icon is still on the site too… we need to find a replacement for that after the launch as well.
 
I also wanted to update you that I’ll be transitioning out of my role here at LCW on July 14
th
. It’s been a great opportunity and I’m proud to have collaborated with talented folks like yourself to redefine the brand and launch a new website, but I’m going to head back into the nonprofit world, specifically in the education space, where my heart truly lies as Director of Marketing and Communications for an org here in Chicago (who also is experiencing an identity crisis after 20 years of work and a new direction). I know I have your email and phone number, but in case you need to reach me my personal email is 
jacob.pieczynski@outlook.com
. 
 
We’re still working out some final transition details, but I think my colleague Ashton Vicente (
a.vicente@lcwmail.com
) will likely be the contact I provide you in case you need anything LCW related moving forward. As this gets finalized, I’ll ask her to reach out to you so you have her contact information.
 
Again, thanks so much for your help! It’s so exciting for this to launch this weekend. Hope it’s a good weekend for you there!
 
Best,
 
Jake 
 
Jacob Pieczynski
(He/Him)

 Wednesday, June 21, 2023 5:27 PM
To:
 Jake Pieczynski <
j.pieczynski@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Re: Invoice update
 
Hey Jake!
 
Hope all has been well. Thanks so much for reaching out and sharing this! Thrilled to see it come to life :)
 
I certainly love the energy and the feeling of the graphics package and how the logo, typography and colors expand the brand. Love it. It feels so much more vibrant, current and friendly. I'm going to have to steal a couple screen grabs of the current site before this goes live.
 
I don't have too much input to make. I really like the typestyling from eyebrow in all caps, the consistent dark blue and weight of the headlines and the body copy works just as I had hoped for when there are some heavy paragraphs of detail.
 
One of my favorite things is when one independent arrow points to a negative space and then solid square. I would try to use that more often over the occasions where it is just negative space and solid square. When possible, I do like when the square shifts to an alternate color from whatever that main section is. (Hope that makes sense)
 
Also like how the logo can be repeated as a pattern in its single-color version. One thing that does throw me a little is the logo slightly rotated when it appears behind a single clipped person. Maybe it's fine as it give some extra life, but there is so much precision to the geometry, I feel some tension.
 
I wonder if the stock photos could be treated somehow to feel more "owned" by the brand. There are so many, it is hard to have a super-consistent style, but I would create some screens. More candid and less-staged would be an important one. One trick that does work, and you can notice it in a few places already, is throwing a slight tone over the top of the image with translucency. See Our Impact page – the one on the bottom with the inset quote is likely my favorite on the whole site. Because the photos are frequent, I'd resist using the logo as a watermark again but maybe some other graphic could be applied. Or another trick would be to use the titles they represent (i.e. TRANSLATION, CONSULTING, CULTURE-FIRST) be the thing that is the watermark. That may be a whole new design language, but you probably get what I mean.
 
Here's one weird comment... the very first icon I saw was the Cross-Cultural icon:
This might be just me, but I see a confused or angry face like I just lost at Angry Birds. And now, you can't un-see that! ;)
 
Thanks for all!
 
Let me know if any of my thoughts are confusing. Happy to chat any time!
 
Take care,
 
Brendan

Hey Jake!
 
That's great to hear. Glad you got away. Gotta love Mexico and esp with a nice all-inclusive. Not having to plan meals and having drinks at the ready is the way to go :)
 
Bad/sad news with Elgin Academy. As Rich predicted, some politics got in the way and FAR into development, they threw our work to a school alum that fancies herself as a branding/marketing expert. The board lead that hired us asked if we wanted to continue as support for her and we said... um, no thanks. Rich thinks they hurt themselves to the point of threatening the school's existence as they haven't created any marketing yet and it was needed in February to recruit new students. It's a real shame. Plus, I loved what we did. Oh well. Maybe they'll come back to us before it closes!
 
I'll let you know when I get something in the mail from the invoice! Thanks for pushing it through :)
 
Take care,
 
Brendan

My girlfriend and I took a real vacation (we took off and weren’t working remote like we normally do) and went to an all-inclusive in Mexico. It was a really nice and needed time with lots of sun and good food. I’m very grateful it worked out and we were able to get the time away!
 
I submitted your invoice and will keep checking on it. If you don’t mind, can you please send me a message when you see it go through? That way I don’t keep bothering them about it. subject: RE: LCW Website Feedback Request
body:
Hi James, 
 
No worries – I hope you’ve been well. The website should be switching over anytime between today and the end of the weekend so if you do want to share any feedback – feel free to check it out next week. I’m excited for the launch too – it’s been a long time coming and while the website’s not perfect it’s going to be an improvement and a great foundation to build from. Thank you for your work researching and putting your time and energy into both the branding and finding the website developer. We certainly wouldn’t be launching this website without your efforts – thank you!
 
Hope it’s a good weekend for you!
 
Best,
 
Jake
